optimize healing  vascular: diuresis was essential for resolution of his cellulitis  problem #3  the renal service followed him during this hospitalization and at their recommendation , spironolactone will be discontinued upon discharge since his diuresis will be slowed  he will need close renal follow ups as he may be approaching need for dialysis 5 by discharge  i have expected his creatinine increase to 4  his electrolytes were replaced as needed 5-2 liters a day was achieved with this regimen with the exception of a 4 liter diuresis overnight on the first day of admission  a diuresis of blood pressure 119/56 , respiratory rate of 20 , o2 sat 99% on room air  family history: asthma and heart disease in three brothers  no history of alcohol use  remote history of tobacco , quit 50 years ago  social history: recently at the orva sonapa alblands in me , otherwise , lives alone in rham en ma at baseline is ambulatory with a walker  allergies: lasix , torsemide , penicillin , erythromycin , capsicum , and quinidine d i  day , and ethacrynic acid 25 mg b  week , protonix 40 mg q  , fosamax 70 mg q d i  , neurontin 100 mg b d i  , calcium 500 mg t 12h  pain , oxycontin 10 mg q n r  p 6h  , oxycodone 5 mg q d i  day , lopressor 25 mg b  medications: colace , senna , lisinopril 5 mg q  past medical history: congestive heart failure , hypercholesterolemia , gastroesophageal reflux disease , venous stasis , t6 fracture and lower back pain , history of herpes zoster with postherpetic neuralgia affecting the right face and ear , atrial fibrillation status post pace replacement , and history of guaiac-positive stools  she denies chest pain or shortness of breath  intake with increasing generalized weakness o  she has significantly decreased p  she also complains of a baseline right ear pain due to her postherpetic neuralgia  she has had flatus  she also states that she has had no bowel movement for a week prior to admission  she describes recent dysuria  she also reported dysphagia for the last two months  she reported nausea and vomiting for eight to nine days , intermittent nonbloody , nonbilious  she had been vomiting and appears severely dehydrated  the patient had returned on the day of admission to see her primary care physician  at the end of this admission , she was sent to a rehabilitation facility  she was treated with diuresis ( ultimately with ethacrynic acid as she developed a rash on torsemide and itching with lasix ) and a seven-day course of levofloxacin  the patient was recently admitted to tapo waycent smouthnew community hospital in early march with a congestive heart failure exacerbation and lower extremity cellulitis  history of present illness: this is an 87-year-old female with a history of congestive heart failure , atrial fibrillation status post pacemaker placement , and chronic venous stasis who presents with nausea , vomiting , and failure to thrive  secondary diagnoses: congestive heart failure , hypercholesterolemia , gastroesophageal reflux disease , venous stasis , postherpetic neuralgia , atrial fibrillation , and urinary tract infection  service: gms ra primary diagnosis: failure to thrive  discharge date: to be determined d"
" heme: the patient's inr was at goal ( 2 to 3 ) on coumadin for her history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation  6  a trial of a lidoderm patch on the affected area was attempted prior to discharge  given her nausea and urinary retention , the patient's opioid medications were decreased  she was admitted on oxycontin and oxycodone , which was titrated out in an attempt to make her more comfortable and neurontin was also titrated out with good effect on her pain  neuro: the patient has postherpetic neuralgia affecting her right face/ear  5  the patient will be discharged to rehab with her foley in place and is scheduled for a follow-up appointment with urology on march , 2005  this was thought most likely due to urinary tract infection and to use opioid medications  she was also noted to have a urinary retention on a few occasions where an attempt was made to remove her foley catheter  the patient has been afebrile through this admission  blood cultures were negative  the urine culture returned was staph aureus ( the patient has had indwelling foley ) and the patient was switched to doxycycline ( the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs , penicillin , and erythromycin )  she was also found to have a urinary tract infection and was initially started on levofloxacin empirically  renal/fen: the patient was initially given intravenous fluids for dehydration  4  the patient had no right upper quadrant pain on this admission  abdominal ultrasound on her last admission in march 2005 showed gallstones , but no other process to explain the abnormalities in alkaline phosphatase  the patient has a history of an elevated alkaline phosphatase ( with elevated ggt ) of unclear etiology  speech and swallow recommended a minced solid/thin liquid diet , which the patient has tolerated well  this study showed no aspiration and normal passage of fluid of varying consistencies ( although a note was made of cricopharyngeal prominence )  a video swallow was obtained on 8/11/05  per speech and swallow , the patient was initially on a soft mechanical/thin liquid diet and is concerned for an obstructive lesion  the patient also complained of dysphagia for two months prior to admission , this occurred mainly with solid foods  intake o  the patient had significantly better p  nausea , vomiting was improved on the day of discharge  the patient's nausea improved with reglan  there is no clear cause for this nausea and vomiting , but it was thought likely to be a contribution of her opioid medications , which were increased early on in her hospitalization to address her postherpetic neuralgia  the patient's nausea and vomiting improved overall throughout her admission , however , intermittently returned  she was continued on nexium for her history of gastroesophageal reflux disease  and began to have her regular bowel movements n r  the patient was given stool softeners and laxatives p  a kub was obtained on admission , which showed no evidence of obstruction or free air  she also reported no bowel movement in the last weeks prior to admission  intake o  gi: the patient had nausea , vomiting for several days prior to admission with decreased p  3  the patient had no clinical evidence of pneumonia ( no cough , lung exam clear )  pulmonary: the admission chest x-ray was read as a streaky opacity of the right lung base possibly representing an infiltrate , but curve has been artifact due to low lung volume  2  she is on coumadin with her inr at goal  she has a pacer placed and is v-paced  rhythm: the patient has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation  c  the patient was also continued on her beta-blocker and ace inhibitor after she was adequately hydrated for blood pressure control  dosing to maintain a slightly negative fluid balance d i  initially , the patient's ethacrynic acid was held given dehydration , but was restarted towards the end of her admission and titrated out to b  her last echo showed an ef of 55% presumed diastolic dysfunction , mild-to-moderate mr as well as pulmonary hypertension of unclear etiology ( pulmonary artery pressure was 64 mmhg plus right atrial pressure )  intake o  pump: the patient was dry on admission in the setting of nausea , vomiting , and decreased p  b  no aspirin was given , as the patient is on coumadin and has a history of guaiac-positive stool  the patient was continued on her beta-blocker  ischemia: no acute issues  cardiovascular: a  hospital course by systems: 1  impression: an 87-year-old female presenting with nausea , vomiting , and dehydration as well as dysuria , most likely mainly due to urinary tract infection secondary to chronic foley placement 0 , amylase 39 , and lipase 14 0 , albumin 4 4 , platelets 448 , 000 , alt 25 , ast 35 , alkaline phosphatase 339 , total bilirubin 1 27 , hematocrit 41 1 , white count was 13  bun was 22 , creatinine 1  labs on admission: remarkable for a chemistry panel within normal limits  the patient did not feel well enough to cooperate with a full neurologic exam , but her strength was symmetric throughout  cranial nerves intact ( except right lid ptosis ) bilaterally  foley in place draining a dark , cloudy urine  abdomen: soft , nontender , nondistended with normal active bowel sounds  lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally  cardiovascular: " infectious disease: the patient was found to have a uti with e  the plan is to continue to monitor her creatinine function , follow up on her urine chemistries and if her creatinine resolves , to resume gentle diuresis as necessary  given her increased creatinine , her ace inhibitor dose was halfed on 10/5/03  diuresis was put on hold on 3/15/03 and 10/5/03  the most likely explanation for increasing creatinine was aggressive diuresis and intravascular volume depletion  repeat urine electrolytes , urine eosinophils and sediment were sent at this point and they are pending at the time of this dictation 7 6 range until 8/21/03 , when her creatinine bumped to 2 and kept rising until 8/3/03 , when it reached 2 5 to 1  her creatinine remained stable in the 1  her urine eosinophils and sediment were unremarkable , but frank proteinuria was noted which is consistent with her known nephrotic syndrome 8 in march of 2003 6 on admission , which is up from about 0  renal: the patient's creatinine was 1  avandia was held given it contraindication in heart failure  her blood sugars were in excellent control on this regimen  endocrine: the patient was continued on nph 20 units for her known diabetes  the patient has chronic folate and iron-deficiency anemia and she was continued on folate and iron replacement  heme: the patient's hematocrit was followed  there was initial concern for pulmonary embolism , but the resolution of symptoms with diuresis and a history that was not suggestive of pulmonary emboli , did not require further followup with spiral chest ct  she has a history of pe as well as dvt and an elevated dimer was found on admission  however , this resolved with diuresis  pulmonary: she initially presented with shortness of breath  the patient will require close followup with careful fluid balance monitoring as well as followup with congestive heart failure service  her other labs were unremarkable including a tsh , which was normal , an ana which was negative , iron studies which did not show iron overload , and thiamine which is pending at the time of this dictation  the patient did not wish for further investigation with cardiac catheterization or a cardiac mri  given the patient's echo findings with depressed ejection fraction and global hypokinesis , a workup for dilated cardiomyopathy was begun  at this point , she was thought to be very close to euvolemic  the patient diuresed about 3 to 4 liters each day during her hospital stay until 2/16/03  her creatinine was carefully followed and did increase on 8/21/03 , at which point diuresis was put on hold d i  she responded to 80 mg of iv lasix t  she was aggressively diuresed with a goal of greater than -2 liters a day  pump: the patient presented with a frank fluid overload with elevated jvp , lower extremity edema , and a bnp greater than assay  given her history of atrial fibrillation as well as depressed ejection fraction , she was restarted on coumadin  she remained asymptomatic with the runs of nsvt and was continued on her beta-blocker  her electrolytes were carefully monitored and repleted as necessary  she was monitored by cardiac telemetry with several episodes of 6 to 10 beats of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia  however , she remained in normal sinus rhythm throughout her admission  rhythm: the patient has a history of atrial fibrillation  however , the patient refused the catheterization  cardiology consult was called and they recommended further workup with cardiac catheterization  however , echo showed global hypokinesis with depressed ejection fraction  an adenosine mibi was performed which was negative for perfusion defects  she was also continued on an ace inhibitor with this switched to captopril as a short-acting ace inhibitor , which was titrated up as tolerated for a goal blood pressure of systolic of 120  she was continued on a low-dose short-acting beta-blocker ( lopressor )  she was ruled out for an mi with negative troponins x 3  the patient was continued on her aspirin as well as statin  cardiovascular: ischemia: there was concern regarding acute and subacute silent ischemia given new st-t wave changes in lateral leads on the ekg  hospital course by system: 1  assessment: this is a 63-year-old woman with history of congestive heart failure who presented with likely congestive heart failure exacerbation  ekg showed sinus bradycardia with a rate of 59 , axis of -36 and no acute changes  chest x-ray showed decreased lung volumes with moderate cardiac enlargement  her bnp was greater than assay and d-dimer was 50 and 69  her troponin was less than assay  her ck was 432 4 , and platelets of 258 7 , hematocrit 39  cbc was significant for white count of 6 6 , and glucose 69 4 , chloride 110 , co2 26 , bun 23 , creatinine 1  laboratory data: on admission , significant for sodium 147 , potassium 3  neurologically , euthymic without focal deficits  extremities with 3+ edema as well as areas of erythematous and shiny shallow ulcerations  abdomen: soft , nontender , and nondistended with positive bowel sound and no hepatosplenomegaly  no murmur , rubs , or gallops  normal s1 and s2  cardiovascular: regular rate and rhythm  chest: crackles bilaterally , left greater than right , half way up both lung fields with mild decreased breath sounds at the bases  neck: supple , jvp at 14 cm  sclerae anicteric  heent: extraocular movements intact  this is an obese female in no apparent distress , sitting up in bed 3 , bp 143/70 , pulse 57 , 98% on 2 liters  physical exam: on presentation , t 97  family history: no family history of heart disease  social history: the patient has a history of 3-packs-per-day smoking for 30 years and no alcohol n r  albuterol p  16 d  q o mg p  medications at home: 1  glaucoma  16  cataracts  15  benign colon polyps greater than 10  14  gastritis  13  arthroscopic knee surgery bilaterally  12  chronic knee and back pain  11 " obstructive sleep apnea procedures: see hospital course history of present illness: the patient is a 54 year old gentleman with a past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus , obesity , coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass grafting and pacemaker placement in 1996 and 1999 respectively , who presented on 9/28/2000 with a four day history of cough , fevers , chills , myalgias and left eye pain  he had been experiencing nausea and vomiting without diarrhea and fevers to 103 degrees 0 centimeter vegetation on the anterior annulus of the tricuspid valve and it was also noted to be hitting the pacemaker wire though not fixed to it  therefore once the infectious work up was completed , the penicillin was changed to vancomycin  the patient's right knee continued to be tender , erythematous and warm during the initial part of the hospitalization r n  septic polyarthritis 3  pacemaker placement 7"
" the patient's inr has been therapeutic in the 2-3 range for approximately five days  q hs o  the patient was anticoagulated for his atrial fibrillation initially with heparin and then ultimately with coumadin 10 mg p  his hematocrit has remained stable with a good reticulocyte count at the time of discharge  the patient received a total of four units of packed red blood cells  the patient was noted to have hematocrit that trended down and corresponded to some guaiac positive stools with anticoagulation  this has improved throughout his hospital course and on the day of discharge his platelets were noted to be 538  hematology: on admission the patient demonstrated a thrombocytopenia with a nadir of 51  6  the patient does have obstructive sleep apnea and used his bipap at night throughout his hospitalization  the patient was initially maintained in the emergency room on high flow oxygen however was quickly weaned to nasal cannula and then room air  pulmonary: the patient was quite stable from a pulmonary standpoint throughout his hospitalization  5  at the time of discharge the patient is experiencing no myalgias or arthralgias with the exception of the right knee which is still somewhat limited in its range of motion and demonstrates an effusion but is responding well to rehabilitation  it was felt that the patient perhaps had a mild episode of rhabdomyolysis which resolved quickly to a ck of 177 five days later  this rise in ck did coincide with increased muscle aches  it was not felt that there was enough manipulation to skeletal muscles during the enucleation to warrant this  it was thought that this was an insignificant mb fraction  the patient after his left eye enucleation , was noted to have an elevated ck of 1522  again , this joint demonstrated elevated white blood cell count but never any clear evidence that it was a septic joint  the patient underwent multiple joint aspirations of the glenohumeral and acromioclavicular joints , both at the bed side and under fluoroscopic examination  the left shoulder was also quite tender during the initial hospital stay  it was determined that the patient should not have this effusion drained again because it was no longer warm or erythematous  since that time the right knee has reaccumulated a moderate sized effusion but the patient has tolerated physical therapy and has regained a moderate amount of his range of motion  the patient continued to have symptoms of right knee effusion and pain and therefore returned to the operating room on 7/2/2000 for repeat arthrocentesis  there were no complications  the patient's knee was lavaged with 9 liters of sterile saline prior to closing all of the effusion was drained  therefore the patient went to arthroscopic examination on 7/24/2000  the patient's right knee continued to be tender , erythematous and warm during the initial part of the hospitalization  there were no bacteria on gram stain or culture  though the fluid did demonstrate elevated white blood cell count it was never clear that these were acutely infected  the patient underwent several arthrocentesis by the rheumatology service  it was though that along with left ophthalmitis , the patient could have septic polyarthritis  musculoskeletal: one of the patient's major presenting complaints was significant arthralgia and myalgia  4  he did rule out for myocardial infarction at the time of admission  the patient's cardiac function appeared to be stable throughout his hospitalization  mild inferior vena cava dilatation consistent with elevated right heart filling pressures  the patient as mentioned above , underwent a transesophageal echocardiogram at the time of admission which demonstrated an ejection fraction of 35 percent , apical hypokinesis , moderately dilated right ventricle with moderately depressed systolic function  his lopressor was increased in response to this and the patient was tolerating this dose without episodes of bradycardia or hypotension  he did have one episode of supraventricular tachycardia thought to be 1-1 conduction of his atrial arrhythmia  he did demonstrate some runs of ventricular tachycardia during the early phase of his hospital course but this resolved as his sepsis resolved  there was some concern throughout the patient's hospital course that the patient would become bradycardic without his pacemaker in place however this never manifested as a problem  the indication for pacemaker placement had been for bradycardia  on 10/16/2000 the patient underwent pacemaker explantation without complications  as mentioned above , the wire did not appear to be incorporated in the vegetation noted on the tricuspid valve however it did appear that the vegetation was hitting the pacemaker wire with systole and diastole  by 8/10/2000 the pacemaker was no longer capturing or sensing  however it rapidly became clear that his pacemaker was malfunctioning demonstrating only occasional pacing spikes  cardiovascular: on admission the patient was noted to have t-wave inversions anteriorly on his electrocardiogram  3  the patient's extraocular muscles were left intact with the thought of placing a prosthesis at a later date  the patient's eye healed well through the remainder of his hospital course and does not appear to be a source of infection thereafter  ultimately the patient had left eye enucleation  the patient was treated initially for his elevated pressure and then the following day his eye was aspirated and injected with vancomycin  it was felt from the time of presentation that the patient would not recover vision in his left eye  ophthalmology: as described above , the patient presented with left eye pain and vision loss  2  his gram positive coverage will need to be continued for four weeks after his left eye enucleation  therefore once the infectious work up was completed , the penicillin was changed to vancomycin  of note , there was concern that the patient's fever could be secondary to a drug reaction  the patient's last positive blood culture was 0/7/2000  it was felt that the low grade fevers were secondary to ongoing inflammation but no acute infectious process at the time of discharge  there was no evidence of any abscess and the vegetation was no longer visible  the patient's fever curve trended down throughout the hospital stay and on the day prior to admission , the patient underwent a repeat transesophageal echocardiogram to ensure that there was no myocardial abscess  as mentioned above the patient was also treated for cellulitis and underwent left eye enucleation  these were interpreted both on the initial views and delayed views as consistent with acute inflammation but not diagnostic of infection  the patient also underwent a tagged white blood cell scan which demonstrated increased uptake in the left shoulder , manubrium , right knee , left ankle and mid shaft of the left tibia  the patient underwent multiple joint aspirations ( see musculoskeletal section below ) without clear evidence of infection  none of these proved to be a source  an extensive work up was undertaken to evaluate the fevers including evaluation for possible epidural abscess , psoas abscess and infected joints  the patient's course was complicated by persistent fevers despite appropriate antibiotic therapy and left eye enucleation  this was treated with a ten day course of dicloxacillin and resolved without complications  the patient also had a right lower extremity cellulitis during his hospital course  it was determined that the patient would require enucleation which he underwent on 0/27/2000  unfortunately the patient continued to spike fever despite appropriate therapy for his gbs and his eye appeared to be worsening with continued erythema , conjunctival edema and a purulent exudate  the patient was injected intraocular with vancomycin at that time  at that time the patient's eye was aspirated and noted to also be infected by gbs  the elevated pressure was treated and he responded well by the following day  the patient presented complaining of left eye pain and loss of vision on the night of admission in the emergency room , the ophthalmologist saw the patient and determined that the patient had an elevated pressure  of note , the bubble study on the echocardiogram was negative for patent foramen ovale 0 centimeter vegetation on the anterior annulus of the tricuspid valve and it was also noted to be hitting the pacemaker wire though not fixed to it 5x1  this demonstrated a 1  a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed on the day of admission and did not demonstrate any vegetation , however with persistent high spiking fevers , sepsis and 4/4 blood culture bottles , repeated blood cultures growing gbs the patient had repeat transesophageal echocardiogram  the patient's antibiotics were changed to penicillin and gentamycin  on the second hospital day , the patient grew 4/4 bottles of what turned out to be group b streptococcus  the patient began to spike fevers from 100 to 101 range  the patient was hydrated aggressively and consistently pan cultured  infectious disease: the patient was initially treated with broad spectrum antibiotics in the emergency room and was rapidly noted to be hypotensive with a systolic blood pressure in the 72  hospital course: 1  urinalysis essentially negative  ct of the head showed no evidence of acute bleed  no focal infiltrates noted  chest x-ray showed cardiomegaly with vascular redistribution  electrocardiogram showed paced rate of 60 with t-wave inversions of v1-v6 5 , hematocrit 33 , platelets 51 7 , cbc showed a white blood cell count of 5  ck 169 , troponin 1 4 , liver function studies otherwise normal  albumen 2 0 ) , otherwise normal 8 ( baseline 1  laboratory data on admission: chemistry panel showed bun 74 , creatinine 2  rectal: guaiac negative brown stool  neurological: nonfocal  difficult to assess  normal bowel sounds  abdomen: obese , soft , nontender and nondistended  2 plus peripheral pulses  extremities: minimal edema , no cyanosis  s3 , loud s2  no murmurs , rubs or gallops  regular rate and rhythm  chest: distant heart sounds  lungs: bibasilar scant crackles  neck: supple without lymphadenopathy , no carotid bruits and no jugular venous distention  heent: os with hazy , edematous cornea , moderately dilated fixed pupil with erythema and injected conjunctiva 2 , heart rate 60 , blood pressure 118/78 , 98% oxygen saturation on 100 percent face mask  physical exam: vital signs: temperature 99  in addition , the patient was cultured and started on broad spectrum antibiotics including ceftriaxone , azithromycin and gentamycin  in the emergency room the patient was given diamox , aspirin and nitropaste in response to t-wave inversions anteriorly on his electrocardiogram  on the day of admission the patient noted the sudden onset of vision loss in his left eye associated with redness and pain  he had been experiencing nausea and vomiting without diarrhea and fevers to 103 degrees  intake had been decreasing o  the patient also noted that the patient should not have this effusion drained again because it was no longer warm or erythematous  since that time the right knee has reaccumulated a moderate sized effusion but the patient has tolerated physical therapy and has regained a moderate amount of his range of motion  the patient continued to have symptoms of right knee effusion and pain and therefore returned to the operating room on 7/2/2000 for repeat arthrocentesis  there were no complications  the patient's knee was lavaged with 9 liters of sterile saline prior to closing all of the effusion was drained  therefore the patient went to arthroscopic examination on 7/24/2000  the patient's right knee continued to be tender , erythematous and warm during the initial part of the hospitalization  there were no bacteria on gram stain or culture  though the fluid did demonstrate elevated white blood cell count it was never clear that these were acutely infected  the patient underwent several arthrocentesis by the rheumatology service  it was though that along with left ophthalmitis , the patient could have septic polyarthritis  musculoskeletal: one of the patient's major presenting complaints was significant arthralgia and myalgia  4  he did rule out for myocardial infarction at the time of admission  the patient's cardiac function appeared to be stable throughout his hospitalization  mild inferior vena cava dilatation consistent with elevated right heart filling pressures  the patient as mentioned above , underwent a transesophageal echocardiogram at the time of admission which demonstrated an ejection fraction of 35 percent , apical hypokinesis , moderately dilated right ventricle with moderately depressed systolic function  his lopressor was increased in response to this and the patient was tolerating this dose without episodes of bradycardia or hypotension  he did have one episode of supraventricular tachycardia thought to be 1-1 conduction of his atrial arrhythmia  he did demonstrate some runs of ventricular tachycardia during the early phase of his hospital course but this resolved as his sepsis resolved  there was some concern throughout the patient's hospital course that the patient would become bradycardic without his pacemaker in place however this never manifested as a problem  the indication for pacemaker placement had been for bradycardia  on 10/16/2000 the patient underwent pacemaker explantation without complications  as mentioned above , the wire did not appear to be incorporated in the vegetation noted on the tricuspid valve however it did appear that the vegetation was hitting the pacemaker wire with systole and diastole  by 8/10/2000 the pacemaker was no longer capturing or sensing  however it rapidly became clear that his pacemaker was malfunctioning demonstrating only occasional pacing spikes  cardiovascular: on admission the patient was noted to have t-wave inversions anteriorly on his electrocardiogram  3  the patient's extraocular muscles were left intact with the thought of placing a prosthesis at a later date  the patient's eye healed well through the remainder of his hospital course and does not appear to be a source of infection thereafter  ultimately the patient had left eye enucleation  the patient was treated initially for his elevated pressure and then the following day his eye was aspirated and injected with vancomycin  it was felt from the time of presentation that the patient would not recover vision in his left eye  ophthalmology: as described above , the patient presented with left eye pain and vision loss  2  his gram positive coverage will need to be continued for four weeks after his left eye enucleation  therefore once the infectious work up was completed , the penicillin was changed to vancomycin  of note , there was concern that the patient's fever could be secondary to a drug reaction  the patient's last positive blood culture was 0/7/2000  it was felt that the low grade fevers were secondary to ongoing inflammation but no acute infectious process at the time of discharge  there was no evidence of any abscess and the vegetation was no longer visible  the patient's fever curve trended down throughout the hospital stay and on the day prior to admission , the patient underwent a repeat transesophageal echocardiogram to ensure that there was no myocardial abscess  as mentioned above the patient was also treated for cellulitis and underwent left eye enucleation  these were interpreted both on the initial views and delayed views as consistent with acute inflammation but not diagnostic of infection  the patient also underwent a tagged white blood cell scan which demonstrated increased uptake in the left shoulder , manubrium , right knee , left ankle and mid shaft of the left tibia  the patient underwent multiple joint aspirations ( see musculoskeletal section below ) without clear evidence of infection  none of these proved to be a source  an extensive work up was undertaken to evaluate the fevers including evaluation for possible epidural abscess , psoas abscess and infected joints  the patient's course was complicated by persistent fevers despite appropriate antibiotic therapy and left eye enucleation  this was treated with a ten day course of dicloxacillin and resolved without complications  the patient also had a right lower extremity cellulitis during his hospital course  it was determined that the patient would require enucleation which he underwent on 0/27/2000  unfortunately the patient continued to spike fever despite appropriate therapy for his gbs and his eye appeared to be worsening with continued erythema , conjunctival edema and a purulent exudate  the patient was injected intraocular with vancomycin at that time  at that time the patient's eye was aspirated and noted to also be infected by gbs  the elevated pressure was treated and he responded well by the following day  the patient presented complaining of left eye pain and loss of vision on the night of admission in the emergency room , the ophthalmologist saw the patient and determined that the patient had an elevated pressure  of note , the bubble study on the echocardiogram was negative for patent foramen ovale 0 centimeter vegetation on the anterior annulus of the tricuspid valve and it was also noted to be hitting the pacemaker wire though not fixed to it 5x1  this demonstrated a 1  a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed on the day of admission and did not demonstrate any vegetation , however with persistent high spiking fevers , sepsis and 4/4 blood culture bottles , repeated blood cultures growing gbs the patient had repeat transesophageal echocardiogram  the patient's antibiotics were changed to penicillin and gentamycin  on the second hospital day , the patient grew 4/4 bottles of what turned out to be group b streptococcus  the patient began to spike fevers from 100 to 101 range  the patient was hydrated aggressively and consistently pan cultured  infectious disease: the patient was initially treated with broad spectrum antibiotics in the emergency room and was rapidly noted to be hypotensive with a systolic blood pressure in the 72  hospital course: 1  urinalysis essentially negative  ct of the head showed no evidence of acute bleed  no focal infiltrates noted  chest x-ray showed cardiomegaly with vascular redistribution  electrocardiogram showed paced rate of 60 with t-wave inversions of v1-v6 5 , hematocrit 33 , platelets 51 7 , cbc showed a white blood cell count of 5  ck 169 , troponin 1 4 , liver function studies otherwise normal  albumen 2 0 ) , otherwise normal 8 ( baseline 1  laboratory data on admission: chemistry panel showed bun 74 , creatinine 2  rectal: guaiac negative brown stool  neurological: nonfocal  difficult to assess  normal bowel sounds  abdomen: obese , soft , nontender and nondistended  2 plus peripheral pulses  extremities: minimal edema , no cyanosis  s3 , loud s2  no murmurs , rubs or gallops  regular rate and rhythm  chest: distant heart sounds  lungs: bibasilar scant crackles  neck: supple without lymphadenopathy , no carotid bruits and no jugular venous distention  heent: os with hazy , edematous cornea , moderately dilated fixed pupil with erythema and injected conjunctiva 2 , heart rate 60 , blood pressure 118/78 , 98% oxygen saturation on 100 percent face mask  physical exam: vital signs: temperature 99  in addition , the patient was cultured and started on broad spectrum antibiotics including ceftriaxone , azithromycin and gentamycin  in the emergency room the patient was given diamox , aspirin and nitropaste in response to t-wave inversions anteriorly on his electrocardiogram  on the day of admission the patient noted the sudden onset of vision loss in his left eye associated with redness and pain  he had been experiencing nausea and vomiting without diarrhea and fevers to 103 degrees  intake had been decreasing o  the patient also noted over the course of four days prior to admission , that his p  obstructive sleep apnea procedures: see hospital course history of present illness: the patient is a 54 year old gentleman with a past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus , obesity , coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass grafting and pacemaker placement in 1996 and 1999 respectively , who presented on 9/28/2000 with a four day history of cough , fevers , chills , myalgias and left eye pain  obesity 9  pulmonary hypertension 8  pacemaker placement 7  coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass grafting 6  diabetes mellitus type ii 5  pacemaker malfunction 4  septic polyarthritis 3  left ophthalmitis 2"
" headache , droperidol 0 n r  q 4 hours p o  , tylenol 650 mg p d i  ( hold if systolic blood pressure less than 110 ) , miconazole 2% powder topical b d i  b o  , trandolapril p d i  b o  q day ( hold if systolic blood pressure less than 110 ) , metformin 1000 mg p o  q day , norvasc 5 mg p o  q day , vancomycin 1000 mg intravenously q 12 hours , coumadin 10 mg p o  , multivitamin with minerals one tablet p d i  b o  , metamucil two packets p d i  q o  metoprolol 50 mg p  regular insulin sliding scale q ac and hs  and q hs m  , regular insulin 15 units q a m  and 35 units q p m  ) , nph insulin 50 units q a m  and 3:00 p m  ( 8:00 a d i  b o  over left eyelid , lasix 160 mg p d i 5% topical t  , ilotycin 0 d i  b o  medications on discharge: colace 100 mg p  also the patient did demonstrate a mild transaminitis during his hospital stay and this appears to have resolved with the transition from penicillin to vancomycin for his antibiotic regimen  this will need to be followed up as an outpatient once the patient has made a full recovery from the acute event  gastrointestinal: the patient did develop guaiac positive stools during his anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation  10  this will likely need to be adjusted as the patient recovers further  the patient was restarted on his metformin prior to discharge and increased dose of nph insulin  he is maintained and nph insulin as well as sliding scale insulin 1 in 8/11 the patient's metformin was held throughout his hospital stay with the anticipation of possible invasive procedures  his hemoglobin a1-c was noted to be elevated at 8 m  and 20 q p m  , nph insulin 25 q a m  and 10 q p m  , regular insulin 10 q a d i  b o  on admission , he was taking metformin 1000 mg p  endocrine: the patient has a long standing history of type ii diabetes mellitus  9  the patient's electrolytes were relatively stable throughout his hospital stay  the patient will require improved nutrition at rehabilitation and after discharge from rehabilitation 3 at the time of discharge  the patient is noted however to have a very poor albumen , which is 2  he also regained his appetite as his sepsis resolved  this responded rapidly to in vitro fertilization  fluids/electrolytes/nutrition: the patient was significant dehydrated at the time of admission  8  this appears to have resolved entirely with resolution of sepsis and rehydration 3 at the time of discharge 0 and stabilized at 1  the patient's creatinine reached a peak of 3  this was thought to be secondary to dehydration and prerenal azotemia 0  renal: on admission the patient was noted to have an elevated creatinine from his baseline of 1  7  the patient's inr has been therapeutic in the 2-3 range for approximately five days  q hs o  the patient was anticoagulated for his atrial fibrillation initially with heparin and then ultimately with coumadin 10 mg p  his hematocrit has remained stable with a good reticulocyte count at the time of discharge  the patient received a total of four units of packed red blood cells  the patient was noted to have hematocrit that trended down and corresponded to some guaiac positive stools with anticoagulation  this has improved throughout his hospital course and on the day of discharge his platelets were noted to be 538  hematology: on admission the patient demonstrated a thrombocytopenia with a nadir of 51  6  the patient does have obstructive sleep apnea and used his bipap at night throughout his hospitalization  the patient was initially maintained in the emergency room on high flow oxygen however was quickly weaned to nasal cannula and then room air  pulmonary: the patient was quite stable from a pulmonary standpoint throughout his hospitalization  5  at the time of discharge the patient is experiencing no myalgias or arthralgias with the exception of the right knee which is still somewhat limited in its range of motion and demonstrates an effusion but is responding well to rehabilitation  it was felt that the patient perhaps had a mild episode of rhabdomyolysis which resolved quickly to a ck of 177 five days later  this rise in ck did coincide with increased muscle aches  it was not felt that there was enough manipulation to skeletal muscles during the enucleation to warrant this  it was thought that this was an insignificant mb fraction  the patient after his left eye enucleation , was noted to have an elevated ck of 1522  again , this joint demonstrated elevated white blood cell count but never any clear evidence that it was a septic joint  the patient underwent multiple joint aspirations of the glenohumeral and acromioclavicular joints , both at the bed side and under fluoroscopic examination  the left shoulder was also quite tender during the initial hospital stay  it was determined that the patient should not have this effusion drained again because it was no longer warm or erythematous  since that time the right knee has reaccumulated a moderate sized effusion but the patient has tolerated physical therapy and has regained a moderate amount of his range of motion  the patient continued to have symptoms of right knee effusion and pain grafted the left thigh skin tear  this team recommended appropriate dressings for the patient's skin tears  the patient was seen by the plastic surgery team  wound healing was impaired secondary to " she was active at baseline able to walk two miles a day without chest pain , dyspnea on exertion , orthopnea , paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea , ankle edema , claudication symptoms , or other symptoms of cerebrovascular disease m  on 4/17/95 with 5/10 substernal chest pain , no shortness of breath , palpitations , diaphoresis , or light headedness , and no prior similar events  there was no recent surgery and no history of bleeds or cerebrovascular accident 2 and her troponin was 20  over the course of several days , her cpk drifted down to 695 to 604 with mb fraction of 46  she did so without any evidence of chest pain , she had no recurrence of chest pain after this point , and on 0/21/96 , the heparin was discontinued and she continued to be pain free with ambulation  on the morning of 11/23/96 , she had an exercise tolerance test , a modified bruce , which was positive  on the morning of 11/23/96 , she had an exercise tolerance test , a modified bruce , which was positive  she came back up to the floor and we discussed doing a catheterization with her  she came in with an inferior/posterior myocardial infarction and was transferred to the coronary care unit after initiation of tpa  she had been followed by dr"
" she was placed on ofloxacin and piperacillin to cover the pseudomonas  chest x-ray showed the evolution of a right basilar consolidation  sputum sent from postoperative day #1 demonstrated pseudomonas in her sputum  she was maintained on triple antibiotics to cover the potential sequela of a superficial cordis site skin infection  she tolerated this procedure well and was transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit  she was taken to the operating room on 9 of march where she underwent four vessel bypass ( lima to lad , saphenous vein graft to r1 and then jumped to om and lastly saphenous vein graft to pda )  she was evaluated for coronary artery bypass grafting  at that time it was decided that her attempts at angioplasty were unsuccessful  the patient also experienced flash pulmonary edema and was transferred to the coronary care unit  the patient however , continued to experience substernal chest pain and dyspnea over the ensuing days  at that time , coronary steps were placed  she did underwent cardiac catheterization 24 of june which revealed 40% residual stenosis of the dominant left circumflex  postoperatively she did well , but had persistent chest pain  the patient underwent pca of her circumflex which at that time was not successful  she underwent cardiac catheterization 7 of july where a 100% proximal dominant circumflex artery stenosis was noted along with 60% proximal lad and 80% rca stenosis  hospital course: the patient was admitted to the cardiology service and ruled in for nonq-wave myocardial infarction  laboratory data: admission - significant for a glucose elevated at 211 , but otherwise normal  rectal - guaiac negative  neurological - nonfocal  distal pulses were 2+ bilaterally  extremities - without edema and without venous varicosities  abdomen - benign with positive bowel sounds and no masses identified  lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally with minimal crackles at the bases  cardiac - revealed a regular rate and rhythm , normal s1 and s2 without murmurs , rubs or gallops  no carotid bruits  there is no jugular venous distention  neck - supple with full range of motion  sclerae are anicteric  oropharynx is clear  head , eyes , ears , nose and throat: no dental pathology 9 , sats are 97% on four liters  blood pressure 142/74 , pulse 78 , respiratory rate 20 , temperature 99  physical examination: she was a morbidly obese woman in no apparent distress  allergies: no known drug allergies d i  , verapamil sr 240 mg b d i  , micronase 10 mg b d  , lisinopril 40 mg q m  p  , 10 q m  a  , regular 45 q m  p  , 45 q m  a  , humulin nph 175 mg q s h  medications: hytrin 20 mg q  angina ( as above )  coronary artery disease  cataract surgery  morbid obesity  hypertension  past medical history: noninsulin dependent diabetes mellitus  the patient was admitted at that time with a diagnosis of nonq-wave myocardial infarction 8  her troponin i came back at 12  ck at that time was 634 with an mb of 30  her ekg at that time demonstrated 2 to 3 mm st depressions in her lateral leads  in the emergency room the patient received aspirin and nitro-paste along with beta blockers  these are not associated with exercise which was new for her  the patient had similar episodes in the same prior to presentation  the patient presented to the hospital with recurrent chest tightness with radiation to her left arm associated with shortness of breath , nausea , vomiting and headache  history of present illness: the patient is a 61 year old woman with a history of chronic renal failure , hypertension , diabetes mellitus and morbid obesity with a long history of coronary artery disease and angina  procedure performed: four vessel coronary artery bypass graft"

admission , which was on june , 2006 , after one day of being discharged from rehab when , during a physical therapy session , the patient accidentally manipulated the foley catheter causing increased stroke  he was in his usual state of health until june , 2006 , when he had a sudden loss of function of his lower upper extremity and lower right extremity  history of present illness: this is a 61-year-old male with hypotension , diabetes , and obesity  admission diagnosis: foley trauma  admission condition: stable d"

" he was started on empiric levofloxacin for questionable pneumonia  physical therapy was consulted to decide whether the patient would benefit from rehabilitation  pa and chest x-ray look good  on postoperative day #4 , he was slightly tachycardic with ambulation and we titrated up on his beta-blockers  on postoperative day #3 , we titrated up his lopressor and started on his norvasc and transferred him to the step-down unit  he was started on lopressor and gentle diuresis  he was found to be hemodynamically stable  he was weaned off his pressors and he was extubated  he was found to have an inferior lateral ischemia on ekg , therefore , he was taken to the cath lab , all grafts were found to be patent and there was resolution of ischemia  he was transferred to the intensive care unit in a stable fashion  the patient's immediate postoperative course was uncomplicated  cletus columbres and a combined decision was made not to replace the aortic valve at this time  this was discussed with his cardiologist , dr 4 and a peak gradient of 30  the patient's aortic valve was only found to be mildly stenotic with the valve area of 1  at which time , he underwent a cabg x3 with a lima to the lad , a saphenous vein graft to the pda and a saphenous vein graft to the obtuse marginal  he was taken to the operating room on 10/3/06  hospital course: he was admitted , made ready for surgery  past medical history: significant for hypertension , dyslipidemia , and chest radiation , prostate cancer , osteoporosis , and urinary incontinence  he was admitted for cardiac catheterization , which was done on 6/14/06 and the patient was found to have a 45% proximal right coronary artery disease , 50% distal left main disease , and 95% mid lad disease  exercise thallium test , which showed increasing lv filling pressures during exercise and inferior apical ischemia  since then , he has done well but he had increasing dyspnea from cr  he had brachytherapy and repeat ptca  he had recurrent ischemic symptoms four months later and cardiac catheterization showed restenosis of his lad with an 80% lesion at d3  history of present illness: this is a 79-year-old male status post stenting of the pda and ptca , radioablation and stenting of his lad in 2000  admitting diagnoses: coronary artery disease and aortic stenosis  service: cardiac surgery service d"
" the patient was discovered to have left leg cellulitis at the knee where his saphenous vein graft was harvested from  the patient was found to have a positive blood culture from when he had been in the intensive care unit and he was continued on levofloxacin  he was found suitable for discharge on postoperative day #5 , however , the patient had isolated temperature and his white count was found to be trending and he was hypertensive  he was started on empiric levofloxacin for questionable pneumonia  physical therapy was consulted to decide whether the patient would benefit from rehabilitation  pa and chest x-ray look good  on postoperative day #4 , he was slightly tachycardic with ambulation and we titrated up on his beta-blockers  on postoperative day #3 , we titrated up his lopressor and started on his norvasc and transferred him to the step-down unit  he was started on lopressor and gentle diuresis  he was found to be hemodynamically stable  he was weaned off his pressors and he was extubated  he was found to have an inferior lateral ischemia on ekg , therefore , he was taken to the cath lab , all grafts were found to be patent and there was resolution of ischemia  he was transferred to the intensive care unit in a stable fashion  the patient's immediate postoperative course was uncomplicated  cletus columbres and a combined decision was made not to replace the aortic valve at this time  this was discussed with his cardiologist , dr 4 and a peak gradient of 30  the patient's aortic valve was only found to be mildly stenotic with the valve area of 1  at which time , he underwent a cabg x3 with a lima to the lad , a saphenous vein graft to the pda and a saphenous vein graft to the obtuse marginal  he was taken to the operating room on 10/3/06  hospital course: he was admitted , made ready for surgery  past medical history: significant for hypertension , dyslipidemia , and chest radiation , prostate cancer , osteoporosis , and urinary incontinence  he was admitted for cardiac catheterization , which was done on 6/14/06 and the patient was found to have a 45% proximal right coronary artery disease , 50% distal left main disease , and 95% mid lad disease  exercise thallium test , which showed increasing lv filling pressures during exercise and inferior apical ischemia  since then , he has done well but he had increasing dyspnea from cr  he had brachytherapy and repeat ptca  he had recurrent ischemic symptoms four months later and cardiac catheterization showed restenosis of his lad with an 80% lesion at d3  history of present illness: this is a 79-year-old male status post stenting of the pda and ptca , radioablation and stenting of his lad in 2000  admitting diagnoses: coronary artery disease and aortic stenosis  service: cardiac surgery service d"
" history of present illness: the patient is a 54 year old , white male with cardiac risk factors of diabetes , borderline hypertension , male gender , and a positive family history , who has no prior cardiac history , but now presents to leyson memorial hospital complaining of substernal chest pain  the patient was maintained on heparin and intravenous nitroglycerin for 72 hours after admission and was started on lopressor and enteric-coated aspirin at admission  the patient did not experience chest pain or shortness of breath during the procedure n"

" in the ccu , she was weaned from iv dobutamine and her blood pressures rapidly came up to systolic blood pressure of 130  at that time , she was transferred to cardiac unit for further management  she was started on dopamine 20 micrograms per kilograms with initially no response  her blood sugar was 181 and ekg at that time showed further t-wave flattening in inferior leads  she was markedly diaphoretic , but did not complain of palpitations  she was noted to be nauseated and vomited x1 with midscapular back pain but no chest pain  she was given a small iv bolus of 100 cc normal saline with no response to her systolic blood pressure  twenty minutes later , patient was noted to be hypotensive with a systolic blood pressure of 70  hospital course: patient was initially admitted to the floor where she received another dose of iv lasix and 30 mg po nifedipine  urinalysis was negative  ekg showed sinus tachycardia at 120 with normal intervals and axis , with some flattening in the stt waves in the lateral lead  chest x-ray was consistent with congestive heart failure with bilateral pleural effusions and increased pulmonary vascular redistribution 41 , 31 , 77 , 23 , and 96%  her first ck was 33 with no mb fraction and an arterial blood gas /showed ph of 7  the differential on her white count demonstrated 82 polys , 12 lymphocytes , 5 monocytes , 1 eosinophil 3 and platelets 352 , mcv 91  cbc showed a white count of 16 with hematocrit of 34 0 , cholesterol 208 , triglycerides 220 1 , calcium 9  albumin was 3  lft's were within normal limits 7 , glucose 220 6 , chloride 106 , bicarbonate 24 , bun 13 , creatinine 0  laboratory evaluation: on admission , sodium was 142 , potassium 4  reflexes were symmetric and toes were bilaterally down-going  cranial nerves were bilaterally intact and motor strength was 5 out of 5 , and sensation was grossly intact as well as her coordination  neuro exam; alert and oriented x3  rectal exam showed no masses and was guaiac negative  extremities; 2+ pitting edema bilaterally with 1+ dp and pt pulses bilaterally without femoral bruits  abdomen; notable for positive bowel sounds , soft , non-tender , non-distended , no hepatosplenomegaly and no other masses felt  cardiac exam showed that she was tachycardic but with a regular rhythm and s1 and s2 were heard clearly with an s4 , there were no murmurs or rubs noted  lungs; rales one-half way up from the bases bilaterally  neck was without adenopathy  jugular venous pressure was 10 cm and the carotids were without bruits  neck exam was supple  oropharynx was clear and sclera were also clear and anicteric  extraocular movements were intact and pupils were equal , round , and reactive to light and accommodation  heent exam was notable for normocephalic , atraumatic head  blood pressure 120/60 , heart rate 120 , respiratory rate 16 , temperature 98 with oxygen saturation 94% on three liters  physical examination: obese , white female in mild respiratory distress  she has a sixty pack year history of smoking but no longer smokes and denies any alcohol use  she lives with daughter  she has several children , all of whom are in good health  family history: notable for both parents who died of myocardial infarctions , mother at age 65 and father at age 75 , both parents also had hypertension and her mother had diabetes  allergies: no known drug allergies n r  , enteric coated aspirin one tablet q day , elavil 25 mg q hs , proventil two puffs q 6 p m  , insulin nph 32 units and 6 units regular q a d o  , lasix 20 mg po q n r 25 mg q hs p  medications on admission: xanax   past medical history: notable for cerebrovascular accident in 1986 , diabetes mellitus since 1985 , she has been insulin dependent; hypertension; congestive heart failure; chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with a long history of smoking  at that point , she was transferred to the floor to the general medical service 4 liters in urine output and her o2 saturation rose to 96% on six liters  she initially responded well to this treatment , diuresing 1  portable chest x-ray was consistent with congestive heart failure and she has been on lasix , morphine sulfate , in addition to nebulizer treatment  she presented to the si to the emergency department after having increased shortness of breath the night preceding the 3 of may and was noted on arrival to the emergency room to have a blood pressure of 200/100 with an oxygen saturation on 100% face mask of 85%  she denies any episodes of chest pain , however , notes that she requires three pillows to sleep on , new onset orthopnea and new onset pedal edema  she has had poor oral intake , however , no change in her bowel habits and no symptoms consistent with an upper respiratory tract infection  the cough was nonproductive  she denies fevers and chills , reports a dry cough but no nausea or vomiting  gieck has become progressively weak and has noted gradually increasing shortness of breath on exertion  since her discharge , ms  an echocardiogram performed during that admission showed normal left and right ventricular function and size 42 estimated at 55% and fev1/fvc ratio 94% cerebrovascular accident in 1986 , who was recently admitted to rahjo voychusetts medical center between 8/0/23 with what was presumed to be an exacerbation of her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and new onset congestive heart failure  history of present illness: ms  peripheral vascular disease  4  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  3  diabetes  2  congestive heart failure  other " her catheterization results suggested that she would be best managed medically and her hospital course then was notable for aggressive diuresis with lasix and one time dose of zaroxolyn , and rate control initially with diltiazem with moderate success and then by the 7th hospital day the addition of lopressor  it was felt at this time that the patient had suffered myocardial infarction at the time between her two sadam medical center admissions  an echocardiogram revealed anteroseptal akinesis at the apex without any mention of thrombus , moderately dilated left ventricle with ejection fraction estimated at 30%  her right heart catheterization showed a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 15 with a diffusely diseased left coronary system , right coronary with serial stenoses of 50% proximal and 30% distal , and anterior apical hypokinesis with preserved lv systolic function 7 on previous admission with the initiation of captopril , she had concurrently an abdominal aortogram to rule out renal artery stenosis   because of her history of acute renal failure with creatinine rising from baseline of 1 to 1  however , after further consideration , she agreed to cardiac catheterization on the 7th hospital day , 1/0/93   the decision to proceed with cardiac catheterization was presented to the patient and on the 4th hospital day , the patient initially refused cardiac catheterization  her ck's were flat and there were no further ekg changes  at that time , the patient was started on heparin 5 , 000 units iv bolus and maintained at 1200 units per hour , and a rule out protocol was again started  ekg post intervention was without change and she was maintained on 3 liters oxygen via nasal cannula , without change in her o2 saturation  she was given 5 mg iv push lopressor q 5 minutes x3 with response of her heart rate to 90  patient was given one tablet of sublingual nitroglycerin with no change in her heart rate and her blood pressure went to 180/60 and she complained of a headache  she did not complain of chest pain , shortness of breath , or diaphoresis  her heart rate at that time was 110 , blood pressure 130/90  soon after transfer , a routine 12 lead ekg revealed deepening and inversion of t-waves in the lateral leads , as well as the inferior leads  on the third hospital day , she was transferred to the cardiology lan tempeo service  she was started on a beta blocker and her rule out protocol for myocardial infarction showed flat ck's , ck's numbering 33 , 58 , and 147 , with no mb fractions and no further ekg changes , and no further episodes of nausea , vomiting , or diaphoresis  her requirement for oxygen was weaned from 100% face mask to 3 liters via nasal cannula , with her o2 saturations remaining 94-95%  in the ccu , she was weaned from iv dobutamine and her blood pressures rapidly came up to systolic blood pressure of 130  at that time , she was transferred to cardiac unit for further management  she was started on dopamine 20 micrograms per kilograms with initially no response  her blood sugar was 181 and ekg at that time showed further t-wave flattening in inferior leads  she was markedly diaphoretic , but did not complain of palpitations  she was noted to be nauseated and vomited x1 with midscapular back pain but no chest pain  she was given a small iv bolus of 100 cc normal saline with no response to her systolic blood pressure  twenty minutes later , patient was noted to be hypotensive with a systolic blood pressure of 70  hospital course: patient was initially admitted to the floor where she received another dose of iv lasix and 30 mg po nifedipine  urinalysis was negative  ekg showed sinus tachycardia at 120 with normal intervals and axis , with some flattening in the stt waves in the lateral lead  chest x-ray was consistent with congestive heart failure with bilateral pleural effusions and increased pulmonary vascular redistribution 41 , 31 , 77 , 23 , and 96%  her first ck was 33 with no mb fraction and an arterial blood gas /showed ph of 7  the differential on her white count demonstrated 82 polys , 12 lymphocytes , 5 monocytes , 1 eosinophil 3 and platelets 352 , mcv 91  cbc " congestive heart failure  history of present illness: ms  portable chest x-ray was consistent with congestive heart failure and she has been on lasix , morphine sulfate , in addition to nebulizer treatment  at that point , she was transferred to the floor to the general medical service  chest x-ray was consistent with congestive heart failure with bilateral pleural effusions and increased pulmonary vascular redistribution  patient was able to ambulate and was stable on discharge"

" headache , estrogen cream topical which is applied to her vagina because of her atrophic vaginitis n r  q four hours p o  discharge medications: tylenol 650 mg p  the patient did quite well with gradual up in her inr to a greater than 2 level and she was discharged to home on 7/26/98 on a regular dose  she was immediately restarted on her coumadin as well as her heparin which she continued for the next three days postoperatively  she was extubated and transferred in stable condition to the postoperative recovery area and observed on the floor  the procedure was done without any complications  on 4/15/98 the patient was taken to the operating room and underwent umbilical hernia repair with primary reapproximation of the fascia  the cardiology felt that in the face of this largely unchanged echocardiogram that showed stable and should go to the operating room for repair of umbilical hernia  this echo was done on 8/20/98 demonstrating an ef of 55% with an abnormal subdural wall motion , trace areas of aortic insufficiency and mildly increased right ventricular size and the artificial mitral valve was noted to be functioning well  the cardiology service was consulted regarding her significant past cardiac history and recommended an echocardiogram to be performed preoperatively 3 and she was , therefore , immediately started on heparin  however , upon arrival here her admission inr was noted to be subtherapeutic at 1  because of her history of coumadinization for both her mitral valve as well as her atrial fibrillation it was felt that it would be "  she was seen by the allergy and immunology service at the request of the cath lab given that there was concern that she had this rash because of her plavix  allergy: during the patient's admission , it was noted that she developed a rash on 10/2/06  6 of her creatinine which is the baseline  her creatinine remained stable throughout her admission and settled out at 1  because of the risk for kidneys , the cath was done with a little amount of dye as possible  she was given mucomyst and bicarbonated fluids for renal protection during her dilute  she was admitted and had a cath 6 5-1  her baseline creatinine was 1  renal: the patient has chronic kidney disease  6  her sugars were relatively well controlled and she did not require much in the way of supplemental insulin  she was switched to coverage with an insulin scale  endocrine: the patient was home on oral hypoglycemics  5  she was treated with vancomycin and ceftazidime and she will complete a 14-day course of these antibiotics  after holding the antibiotics for three days , her white count began to rise and she developed a purulent cough as noted above , this was thought to be a hospital-acquired pneumonia  she had completed three weeks of therapy and thus we discontinued this medication as it did not seem that there was really any evidence of active infection in her foot  infectious disease: the patient was initially admitted on augmentin for a diabetic foot ulcer , the notes from grantnas healthcare by the infectious disease service recommended a 2-4 week course of augmentin for her diabetic foot ulcer  4  we felt comfortable with discharging her with close follow up  clinically , she appeared to improve on this regimen , although her white count was still elevated at 15 on discharge , however , given her overall clinical stability , the lack of fevers and the lack of systemic symptoms  she was treated for a hospital-acquired pneumonia with vancomycin and ceftazidime to complete a 14-day course  the gram-negative rods were later speciated as serratia although this information is not available at the time of her discharge  we held her antibiotics as noted below in the id section and after that her white blood cell count increased and she produced some purulent sputum and gram-negative rods  however , she did not appear to clinically respond to this medication  we initially continued her on augmentin , which she was taking for her diabetic foot ulcer  a chest x-ray on admission showed a right lower lobe infiltrate/atelectasis  pulmonary: the patient was admitted with crackles in the left lower lobe and some wheezing consistent with copd and pneumonia  3  it was unclear what the etiology of this diarrhea was and we were going to send a repeat stool study , however , she did not have any diarrhea afterwards and this may be antibiotics associated diarrhea but it seemed to resolve spontaneously  diff was negative  her fecal leukocytes were positive but her c   the diarrhea resolved one day after admission  gi: the patient was admitted with persistent nausea and diarrhea from tlmamuthes medical center   2  c: rhythm: the patient was kept on telemetry , however , there were no significant episodes of arrhythmias during her admission  this can be restarted  we did not diurese her in fact we held her lasix on admission because she seemed to be volume depleted given that she was admitted with a lot of diarrhea , this again will need to be reconsidered if she had increased edema  it was on the lower side here , so we did not add it  this medication should be added as an outpatient , if her blood pressure tolerates it  given that she has a concurrent renal disease , it would probably be useful for her to be on an ace inhibitor arb as well  from 25 mg daily as her requirement of beta blockade seemed to be higher than what her home dose was d i  we did increase her dose of atenolol to 25 mg b  however , at discharge , this was switched back to atenolol as her home medications and she refused to change medications , she said that she would not be able to afford new prescription  she was continued on her beta blocker as noted above  she remained in a blood pressure range of 100-120 throughout her stay  pump: the patient had no significant issues with her blood pressure here  b  after her cath , it was originally planned that she would go back to cath for intervention on the left circulation lesion , however , given her other medical problems and her relative stability hemodynamically and symptomatically , it was decided that they would wait and decide later if this lesion needed to be corrected in the future or not d i  she was also continued lipitor 80 mg daily , lopressor 25 mg t  instead of plavix for anticoagulation d i  she was started on aspirin and plavix initially although as noted below she did have an apparent allergy to plavix and thus was switched to ticlopidine 250 mg b  she did not complain of any chest pain or nausea and vomiting during her admission  her post cath ecg was unchanged and continued to have the deep lateral t wave inversions  because of her kidney insufficiency , it was decided not to pursue the 80% left circ lesion and this was deferred until later point as this was not thought to be causing any problems  this was stented with a taxus stent  they also saw that there was a proximal rca lesion 60% which was found to account for the inferior hypokinesis given the right arm circulation  she was taken to the cath lab on 11/2/07 and they show two ____ that one of the bypass grafts was completely occluded and was not visualized  the echocardiogram as noted above showed inferior hypokinesis consistent with coronary artery disease  it was decided on admission that an echocardiogram would be performed and if there was evidence of any regional wall motion abnormalities that she would be taken directly to cath  ischemia: the patient was admitted because they had deep t wave inversions in the lateral leads and are still concerning for anginal equivalence of nausea and vomiting  cardiovascular: a  hospital course by problem: 1  there is trace tricuspid regurgitation with a pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 36 mm plus right atrial pressure  there was mild mitral regurgitation 2 cm2  the valve area was 1  mild-to-moderate aortic regurgitation  there was mild aortic stenosis  the rv was normal  the coronary artery bypass grafts had a patent lima to lad graft , the svg to marginal i had a 100% lesion during this catheterization due to the moderate amount of contrast and the patient's chronic kidney disease , they treated the rca and placed a 3 x 24 mm taxus stent echocardiogram: on 11/0/07 , showed an estimated ejection fraction of 50% with inferoseptal and inferior severe hypokinesis  the rca had a proximal 75% lesion with a mid diffuse 60% lesion and a plv tubular 70% lesion  the lad had a tubular 90% lesion and the diagonal i had a proximal tubular 60% lesion , there was also a diffuse 80% lesion of the proximal circumflex  there were no significant left main lesions identified  findings: showed a right dominant circulation  eeds in her foot  infectious disease: the patient was initially admitted on augmentin for a diabetic foot ulcer , the notes from grantnas healthcare by the infectious disease service recommended a 2-4 week course of augmentin for her diabetic foot ulcer  4  we felt comfortable with discharging her with close follow up  clinically , she appeared to improve on this regimen , although her white count was " he was admitted to the hospital for broad-spectrum antibiotics ( cefepime and vancomycin ) and subsequently developed hypotension requiring vasopressor support with dopamine as well as an increased oxygen requirement  he was initially thought to have left lower lobe pneumonia , but subsequently left knee effusion was noted and an arthrocentesis was performed with consistent with septic arthritis  goettl is an 83-year-old gentleman with a history of coronary artery disease , congestive heat failure , diabetes , and chronic renal insufficiency , status post bilateral knee replacement 10 years prior who presented to an outside hospital on the february , 2005 , with one day of mild confusion , fever , and lethargy  history of present illness: mr  admission diagnosis: septic shock from right prosthetic knee , infection with mrsa d"
" he was sent to the step down unit on routine postoperative day number two and his captopril was increased for afterload reduction  the gastrointestinal service saw any evidence of any upper gastrointestinal bleed and he was maintained on h2 blockers  he was again extubated and was seen in consultation by the gastrointestinal service for a question of gastrointestinal bleed since there was a clot seen on the transesophageal echocardiogram probe at its withdrawal from his first surgery  after he was extubated , he was reintubated and was returned in good and stable condition to the intensive care unit on renal dopamine  on postoperative day number one , he was taken back to the operating room for bleeding  on postoperative day number one , he was weaned to extubation and he was treated with stress steroids to prevent steroid withdrawal  his intraoperative course was uncomplicated  hospital course: on march , 1999 , he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting times three with a left internal mammary artery to the left anterior coronary artery , saphenous vein graft to the aorta and a saphenous vein graft from the obtuse marginal to the aorta  chest x-ray revealed no proximal lesion of the left anterior descending coronary artery , 80% lesion distal to d1 , 100% occlusion of his left circumflex and a 100% occlusion of his right coronary artery"

" history of present illness: this is a 52 year old male with insulin dependent diabetes mellitus , but no previous coronary artery disease or other cardiac risk factors , who presented with 24 hours of chest pain he described as starting on march in the evening , at rest , involving his entire chest , as well as both arms , without any associated symptoms of shortness of breath , nausea or vomiting , lightheadedness or palpitations  which was converted to once a day atenolol  he underwent a submax ett prior to discharge , went 9 minutes without any chest pain or ekg changes and was discharged to home on july , 1997 n"
" since the patient had slightly high blood pressures with systolics in the 160-170 range , he was started on lisinopril 10 mg q  the patient remained chest pain free throughout his hospital course and developed no evidence of arrhythmia while on the cardiac monitor  which was converted to once a day atenolol d i  initially , lopressor 25 mg q  he was also started on aspirin , beta blocker  he was started on iv heparin which was continued for 48 hours and then discontinued  hospital course: the patient was admitted on july , 1997 with a diagnosis of acute non-q wave mi  no other family members have coronary disease  family history: his uncle has coronary artery disease  his ldl was 123 in march of 1991  he lives with his family and he works in telecommunications  he occasionally drinks alcohol  social history: patient smoked 1/2 pack per day of cigarettes and quit in 1991  chest x-ray showed no active disease , no evidence of infiltrates or cardiomegaly or effusions  ekg noted  abdomen showed normal active bowel sounds , soft , nontender , nondistended  pulmonary exam is clear to auscultation  carotids are 2+ without bruits  neck showed no jugular venous distension  cardiac exam shows a regular rate and rhythm , no murmurs , rubs or gallops noted  heent exam is unremarkable  the patient is in no apparent distress  room air saturation is 93% 4 , blood pressure 160/86 , pulse 90  physical examination: patient's temperature is 99  allergies: none known  medications: nph insulin 60 units in the morning and 30 units in the evening  again , he has no prior coronary artery disease  he also has a history of obesity  he also has a history of burns in august of '96 requiring skins grafts  past medical history: insulin dependent diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy and impotence  again , he was observed for some time in the emergency room until his first troponin came back positive at 28 , at which time he was admitted with a diagnosis of myocardial infarction  in the roniga hospital of emergency room , he was given aspirin and oxygen with immediate improvement in his pain from a 4/10 to 2/10 , and was made pain free after one sublingual nitroglycerin  at nuomc , an ekg showed flat to inverted t waves laterally  he had no relief with tums on the morning of the 3 of may , and came into the glas hospital care emergency room  the pain lasted all night but he was able to sleep through this pain  he states that the discomfort was constant , nonpleuritic and not changed by position  history of present illness: this is a 52
