bipap was started  she had severe hypotension and was on two pressors  cardiovascular: she had a mild troponin elevation on admission , likely secondary to rv strain  2  she multiple times refused bipap while in the hospital , but she will go back on it when she returns home  her o2 saturations were acceptable in-house , although she did desaturate to 90% when she took her oxygen off a night  she was on face mask , and upon transfer to the floor , she was on nasal cannula 4 liters  she was never intubated  she was initially on oxygen in the icu  the working hypothesis is that there was a significant recanalization prior to this repeat ct which took place two days after the first ct  her second pect showed a small pe to the right upper lobe , but it was not large enough to explain her dramatic presentation  she was started on heparin drip with a goal of 60 to 80  a vq scan showed intermediate probability  her initial pe scan was nondiagnostic secondary to poorly timed contrast and motion of the patient  an echo showed a dilated rv with depressed rv function suggestive of pe  pulmonary/vascular: there was initial concern for a pe given the presentation of severe hypotension , tachycardia , and aa gradient without evidence of infection or primary cardiac disease  hospital course by system: 1  presentation was most consistent with right pulmonary embolus and right ventricular failure  assessment and plan: this is a 49-year-old woman with a recent icu stay at an outside hospital who presented with hypotension , tachycardia , and acute renal failure  laboratory studies on admission: please see lmr  her strength was intact  neurologically , she was alert and oriented , but unfocused in conversation , moving all her extremities  the ankles were without swelling and with full range of motion  extremities were without erythema of her legs , but with mild swelling of the right lower ankle  her abdomen was obese , + bowel sounds , nontender and nondistended  jvp was difficulty to ascertain secondary to neck habitus  cardiovascular: she was tachy , regular , but distant s4  pulmonary: she had decreased breath sounds and crackles at the bases bilaterally  she had a thick neck  she is anicteric , without pallor  she was awake and alert and in no acute distress  physical examination: she was afebrile , heart rate in the 100's , blood pressure 130/80 , respiratory of 18 , and o2 saturation 95% on 8 liters of oxygen  she is on disability  she lives at home , but does not work  no illicit drugs  no alcohol for three years  social history: she smoked half a pack a day for 30 years  allergies: she is allergic to penicillin and sulfa drugs  she has in the past taken lisinopril with hydrochlorothiazide  she is not taking her lisinopril  medications at home: lisinopril and methadone  in a well state , her pco2 was 49 , her o2 saturation is 89% , and she has also history of depression  she has a questionable diagnosis of copd with her extensive smoking history  she was treated with cefepime at that time , questionable the vancomycin  she had enterobacter pneumonia  she had a klonopin overdose  she has chronic right lower extremity pain and she is on methadone  she had a right ankle injury more than 20 years ago during the motor vehicle accident , which was complicated by an ankle infection  she has obstructive sleep apnea , on her home bipap , morbid obesity , and hypertension  past medical history: she had endocarditis 20 years ago  in the micu , her blood pressure was stabilized on levophed , but she was also noted to drop her blood pressure to the 70's when initiated on her home bipap settings  chest x-ray showed cardiomegaly , but otherwise clear  her ekg was notable for low voltage on precordial leads and borderline right axis deviation  she was aggressively given fluids and was started on levophed for blood pressure support  she was given vancomycin , levaquin and gentamicin and 3 liters of normal saline  in the ed , her vital signs were that she was afebrile , her systolic blood pressure was in the high 60's , her heart rate was 110 , respiratory rate in the 30's , and o2 saturations were in the high 80's  she then came to the ed at town medical center and clinics for persistent shortness of breath and dizziness  she was not admitted  her family is not clear on her discharge " because of his shortness of breath he was started on lasix for 3-4 days but this also did not relieve his symptoms  verdun   over the past month he had been seeing his cardiologist , dr  he did not take any nitroglycerin but his wife told him that he was \"gasping for breath\"  on the morning of admission he felt chest heaviness that woke him up from sleep  then two days prior to admission the patient also noticed pain at rest but was again relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin  he has had increased difficulty walking up the stairs causing chest pain and shortness of breath that are relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin  over the past few months the patient has also noticed increased angina , both with and without activity  he was seen as an outpatient and found to have frequent pvcs on ekg  he decreased his atenolol to 25 mg once a day but his symptoms persisted  his wife and son , who are a nurse and a pa , respectively , felt his pulse and it was frequently in the 30s , but was also occasionally normal  at the time for his coronary artery disease d i  b o  he was being treated with atenolol 25 mg p  he had recently developed bacteremia after a colonoscopy and never felt that he had quite recovered  history of present illness: the patient's symptoms first developed last july , 2002 when he noticed fatigue and shortness of breath"
"record #461076   077681263 | nth | 32812636 | | 2211126 | 0/18/2003 12:00:00 am | congestive heart failure | signed | dis | admission date: 4/24/2003 report status: signed  discharge date: 4/28/2003 chief complaint: this is a 72-year-old man with a history of significant coronary artery disease , status post cabg x 2 , stents and brachytherapy who was admitted for an nsvt leading to fatigue and shortness of breath  he had recently developed bacteremia after a colonoscopy and never felt that he had quite recovered  he has had increased difficulty walking up the stairs causing chest pain and shortness of breath that are relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin  he had holter monitoring with exercise , going up and down the stairs , at clinic and this also showed frequent pvcs  after his heart rate was controlled with amiodarone and with a pacemaker , he did however continue to have some fatigue and shortness of breath  it is possible that the symptoms that he had later on in the hospitalization were secondary to volume overload which responded well to diuresis  2 ) pump: the patient did experience some shortness of breath several days into his admission  he responded well to 20 mg iv lasix"
" his hematocrit went to 17  6 ) heme: the patient does have a history of a gi bleed on aspirin and plavix  given his history of radiation proctitis and proctatitis it is not surprising that he had this  his bypass vessels are lima/lad , svg/marginal 1 , lima/lad , svg/rpda  he responded well to 20 mg iv lasix  he came in at 37  he had a coronary artery bypass graft in 1974 and 1982  we held his metformin on admission because of his catheterization but restarted it upon discharge  he will have pulmonary function tests as an outpatient to establish a baseline given his new treatment with amiodarone  he had holter monitoring with exercise , going up and down the stairs , at clinic and this also showed frequent pvcs  this may ultimately be decreased even further to 200 but will be decided by dr  5 ) pulmonary: as mentioned above the patient did have some shortness of breath which was likely due to volume overload  over the past month he had been seeing his cardiologist , dr  he also had a number of beats shortened that would be required to detect the vt , to 24  4 ) endocrinology: the patient has a history of diabetes  then two days prior to admission the patient also noticed pain at rest but was again relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin  he had an icd and ddi pacemaker placed on 5/26 without complication d  he was seen as an outpatient and found to have frequent pvcs on ekg d  as a result his settings were adjusted to increase his av delayed 240 and he was changed to ddd mode  at the time for his coronary artery disease o  he also required an additional 150 mg iv x 1 load to stabilize his rhythm  b  the nsvt never progressed to sustained v-tac and the patient was always hemodynamically stable i  he had recently developed bacteremia after a colonoscopy and never felt that he had quite recovered  he was sent home with 20 mg of lasix q"

increased to 90 mg q  , she had heart rate to the 160s , again was treated with diltiazem 20 mg iv x1 and her heart rate decreased to the 90s m  on 9/29/05 , at 2:00 a  was then added to her regimen d i  q o  diltiazem 60 mg p  she was treated with lopressor 5 mg followed by diltiazem 20 mg x2 , which then caused reduction in the heart rate to the 90s  with heart rates in 200 range m   the event on 10/11/05 occurred at 5:00 p  from a cardiovascular standpoint , her hospital stay was complicated by two distinct episodes of supraventricular tachycardia with rapid ventricular response , one on 10/11/05 and one on 9/29/05   in terms of her history of acute renal failure , the creatinine had continued to decrease through her hospitalization , but after aggressive diuresis , she had slight increase in her creatinine , but this responded well to reducing the rate of lasix and mild hydration n r  she is being treated with imodium p  the suspicion is low  diff cultures were sent , both are pending at this time  given history of pervious antibiotic use for uti , c  as an aside , she developed diarrhea while in-house  and tolerated regular house feeds prior to discharge with no emesis n r pertinent review of systems: she denied any symptoms of orthostasis  therefore , on 4/24/05 , she was transferred from the nursing home to the baview hospital and medical center for evaluation of the hematemesis  she did have a history of sick contact , her previous roommate , during the hospitalization had gastroenteritis  she has no abdominal pain , diarrhea , or constipation  her symptoms progressed over the night and continued throughout the next day , and she presented with complaints of coffee-ground emesis without melena , dizziness , orthostasis , or palpitations  she was discharged to the nursing home on that day and experienced mild nausea and emesis that evening  she was recently discharged from the tohall villeviewtrom moralb medical center on 10/23/05 after admission for uti and acute renal failure in the setting of nsaid abuse because of low back pain  history of present illness: this is a 75-year-old female with a history of type ii diabetes mellitus , insulin dependent , as well as a history of chf and supraventricular tachycardia in addition to a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease , hiatal hernia and esophageal stricture status post three dilations in the remote past  problems/diagnoses considered during the hospitalization: hematemesis , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus; uncontrolled , hypertension , congestive heart failure , " he was started on heparin for the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction  he was started on simvastatin given his hypercholesterolemia  hospital course: the etiology of his symptoms was unclear , but he was admitted to rule out myocardial infarction , given the fact that he had a left bundle branch block pattern on his ekg that was new compared to a previous ekg  he was maintained on aspirin and started on a beta blocker  ekg , on admission , showed sinus rhythm at a rate of 30 with the left bundle branch pattern that was new compared with an ekg from 6/1 his axis and intervals were normal  it was not known whether this new ekg finding was acute or whether this had occurred sometime between 5/23 and the present time  his cardiac troponin was 0  a chest x-ray demonstrated a right lower lobe opacity and bilateral pleural thickening , no acute infiltrate , and no evidence of congestive heart failure  his liver function tests were normal 0  his white blood cell count was 7 babinski's test bilaterally  serum glucose was 204  his touch sensation was intact in his lower extremities bilaterally  laboratory data: electrolytes were within normal limits with bun 24 and creatinine 1  his skin was warm and moist without any lesions  he had normal biceps and patellar deep tendon reflexes bilaterally  his stool was heme occult negative  neurologic examination showed an alert and oriented man with fluent speech and 5/5 motor strength in his upper extremities and lower extremities bilaterally  his liver span was estimated at 6 cm by percussion  extremities were without any evidence of cyanosis , clubbing , or edema  his abdomen appeared obese with active bowel sounds  he did not have any splenomegaly  there was also question of a grade i/vi systolic murmur at the left sternal border and apex  it was soft and nontender  no s3 was heard  he had good radial and dorsalis pedis pulses  his heart rate sounded somewhat fast , but was regular  there was a question of a fourth heart sound  no muscle spasm was palpable  his heart sounds were distant with an indistinct first heart sound , but a second heart sound without evidence of splitting  his neck was nontender to palpation  his lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally  oropharynx was without any evidence of lesions or without any adenopathy or masses  his back was nontender to palpation  pupils were equal , round , and reactive to light  there was no jugular venous distention apparent and no bruits heard  heent examination was notable for a 5 mm nodule on the palpebral margin of his right upper eyelid  extraocular muscles were intact 5 , heart rate between 90 and 100 , blood pressure 144/96 , respiratory rate 16 , and oxygen saturation 95% on two liters by nasal cannula  sclera were anicteric  he claims he quit smoking in 1990 after a 40 pack year history  he appeared to be a middle aged man who was comfortable lying in bed  his wife died in the last year , just after having undergone a coronary arterial bypass graft  physical examination: his temperature was 98  there is no family history of diabetes mellitus or hypertension  he has three children who lives in the area rest  he denied any paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or swelling of lower extremities  he continued to feel weak  this has not changed recently and seems stable  he denied any chest pain , shortness of breath , or palpitations  he was noted at tfhc to have a left bundle branch block on his ekg that was new compared to an ekg obtained in 6/1 he was , therefore , referred to mibo hospital for further evaluation and management  the shooting sensation from his shoulder up to his head was accompanied by a near loss of consciousness and was followed immediately by flushing with diaphoresis and then weakness and dizziness that persisted for about 5-10 minutes  he pulled his car over to the side of the road and had his friend drive him to ttfc  he has had a normal head ct in 0/8 this pain has been responsive to physical therapy and traction in the past  he did feel nauseated , but did not vomit  x-rays have shown degenerative arthritis in the cervical spine , especially in the region of c6 and c7 with evidence of foraminal narrowing and nerve root impingement  today , he had a similar such episode while turning his head to the right while driving his car  he does not know how often he has them , but does not think that he has had more of these episodes recently  he also has evidence of multiple osteophytes in his cervical spine and in the region of his left shoulder  he has a history of intermittent episodes of sudden onset of an ill defined , non-painful sensation that shoots from the region of his left shoulder , up his left neck , and then across his head bilaterally  he has previously been worked up for chronic neck and left shoulder pain that is attributed , in part , to a history of trauma  history of present illness: mr  the episodes are usually instantaneous  6 the baseline creatinine of 2  the patient now presents with bleeding from the site of the left toe amputation beginning two weeks ago associated with throbbing pain , soreness , erythema and swelling and exacerbated blood pressure when walking and only treated by narcotics  an mra on 10/3/06 demonstrated on the right a multifocal high-grade stenosis of the proximal , anterior tibial , the posterior tibial arteries and occlusion of the peroneal artery in the dorsalis pedis  the patient presented on 3/26/05 for a nonhealing ulcer for three weeks' duration , exposed bone on the left great toe and was admitted for debridement and antibiotics 5 months status post left toe amputation on 7/1/06 complicated by acute on chronic renal failure and delirium requiring postoperative dialysis from " the patient's coumadin was continued in-house for a goal inr of between 2 to 3  his qtc was monitored throughout this process , and the plan was for a transesophageal echocardiogram and dc cardioversion on 3/15/2006 for further treatment of the atrial fibrillation  it was decided to proceed with dofetilide therapy on 7/13/2006  atrial fibrillation: given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and flutter since 2000 and his continued symptoms on toprol ( amiodarone was not an option that the patient wished to pursue given the side effects of skin discoloration that he had previously experienced )  2  the patient was continued on aspirin and zetia for hyperlipidemia  there were no symptoms or signs consistent with ischemia in-house  the plan was to restart his ace inhibitor following complete diuresis to dry weight  his toprol was continued in-house , but his ace inhibitor was held in the setting of increases in his serum creatinine  daily on 7/13/2006 o  he was switched over to lasix 80 mg p 5 l , and he did very well on this dose of lasix for the in and out goal  the daily goal for his was -2 to 2 6  on presentation , he was compensated for his congestive heart failure , with a creatinine of 1  congestive heart failure: the patient was started with a diuretic regimen of lasix 40 mg iv twice a day given that he appeared to be volume overloaded by clinical exam  hospital course by problem: 1  procedures: on 6/15/2006 , the patient was started on dofetilide  chest x-ray , 6/30/2006 , shows cardiomegaly with an interstitial process and without effusions  there is a dilated aortic root  mild mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation  there is a hypokinetic mid to distal wall , posterior and inferior wall  septum is thin and akinetic at the apex 8% 2%; end-systole 4  left ventricular diameter , end-diastole , 6  echocardiogram , 6/30/2006 : ejection fraction 30%  no st changes  normal intervals  ekg showed atrial fibrillation with ventricular rate in the 70s  lipids: total cholesterol 121 , triglycerides 166 , hdl 37 , ldl 51 3 , platelets 196 , 000  white blood cells 599 , hematocrit 39  bnp 659 3 , alkaline phosphatase 66  alt 26 , ast 29 , total bilirubin 0 6 , glucose 218 2 , bun 33 , creatinine 1  admission laboratory data: sodium 137 , potassium 5  his neuro exam is grossly intact , and he is alert and oriented x3  extremities are warm and well perfused with 2+ pulses and 1+ pitting edema from ankles to thighs bilaterally  his abdomen is obese , mildly tender without hepatosplenomegaly  his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally  no heave or palpable thrill  no s4 or rub  soft systolic murmur at the right lower sternal border  his heart exam is irregularly irregular with abnormal s1 and s2 , soft s3  neck shows jvp is approximately 7 cm  generally , this is a comfortable-at-rest-appearing gentleman in no respiratory distress 7 , heart rate 80 , blood pressure 144/78 , respiratory rate 20 , o2 saturation 97% on room air  admission physical examination: vitals were temperature of 95  allergies: flagyl to which he gets edema and demerol  family history: significant for brother who died of an mi at age 58 , father who died of an mi at age 78 , and mother with atherosclerosis  he does have an occasional glass of wine or two at dinnertime  he does not drink excessively  he does not smoke  he currently lives in jo car mont with his wife  tota is a retired lobbyist  social history: mr  coenzyme q10  20  folic acid  19  zinc  18  magnesium  17  vitamin b12  16  vitamin c  15  multivitamin  14  nexium 40 mg daily  13  elavil 10 mg daily  12  lantus 24 units subcutaneously daily  11 d i  glyburide/metformin 2-5/500 mg b  10  pravachol 40 mg daily  9  zetia 10 mg daily  8  aspirin 81 mg daily  7  k-dur 10 meq every monday and friday  6  lasix 20 mg every other day  5  amiodarone 200 mg daily  4 5 mg on tuesday and thursday  coumadin 5 mg on monday , wednesday , friday , saturday , and sunday; 7  3  diovan 160 mg daily  2 d i  toprol xl 50 mg b  preadmission medications: 1  he was admitted for diuresis in the setting of a chf exacerbation and for consideration of options in the treatment of his atrial fibrillation  gabard 's clinic on the day of admission for evaluation  given his worsening symptoms , he presented to dr  he was started on amiodarone on 4/13/2006 for atrial fibrillation  he endorses worsening orthopnea and pnd over the several weeks prior to admission  electrophysiology adjusted his icd , still he reports continued symptoms as previously described as well as decreased appetite and weight gain of 15 pounds over 6 weeks  consequently , ett was done on 9/15/2006 , which was terminated after 1 minute when the patient's heart rate went up to 130  he continued to feel even more unwell towards the later end of march , with episodes of nausea , diaphoresis , shortness of breath , and abdominal pain with exertion ( these were his typical angina symptoms in the past )  given his increased risk for sudden death , a single-chamber icd was placed  an echocardiogram was done in march 2006 , showing an ejection fraction of 28%  he was cardioverted in july 2006 , resulting in symptomatic improvement until march 2006 when he again reportedly felt weak , had increased dyspnea with exertion  he was found to be in atrial fibrillation and was started on coumadin , with continuation of the toprol for rate control  in august 2006 , he notes that he began to feel weak with increased dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations , although he denied any chest pain  history of present illness: this is a 77-year-old male with a history of cad , chf with an ejection fraction of 30% , atrial fibrillation ( diagnosed in 2000 , status post 4 cardioversions , on amiodarone until march 2005 , when it was discontinued due to skin discoloration; since then , the patient has been on toprol ) , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , who has done well since a stent was placed in 2002 , not requiring any hospitalizations for cardiac-related issues  hypertension  2  insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus  list of problems and diagnoses: 1  atrial fibrillation and flutter  2  chf exacerbation"
" his qtc was monitored throughout this process , and the plan was for a transesophageal echocardiogram and dc cardioversion on 3/15/2006 for further treatment of the atrial fibrillation  it was decided to proceed with dofetilide therapy on 7/13/2006  atrial fibrillation: given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and flutter since 2000 and his continued symptoms on toprol ( amiodarone was not an option that the patient wished to pursue given the side effects of skin discoloration that he had previously experienced )  2  the patient was continued on aspirin and zetia for hyperlipidemia  there were no symptoms or signs consistent with ischemia in-house  the plan was to restart his ace inhibitor following complete diuresis to dry weight  his toprol was continued in-house , but his ace inhibitor was held in the setting of increases in his serum creatinine  daily on 7/13/2006 o  he was switched over to lasix 80 mg p 5 l , and he did very well on this dose of lasix for the in and out goal  the daily goal for his was -2 to 2 6  on presentation , he was compensated for his congestive heart failure , with a creatinine of 1  congestive heart failure: the patient was started with a diuretic regimen of lasix 40 mg iv twice a day given that he appeared to be volume overloaded by clinical exam  hospital course by problem: 1  procedures: on 6/15/2006 , the patient was started on dofetilide  chest x-ray , 6/30/2006 , shows cardiomegaly with an interstitial process and without effusions  there is a dilated aortic root  mild mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation  there is a hypokinetic mid to distal wall , posterior and inferior wall  septum is thin and akinetic at the apex 8% 2%; end-systole 4  left ventricular diameter , end-diastole , 6  echocardiogram , 6/30/2006 : ejection fraction 30%  no st changes  normal intervals  ekg showed atrial fibrillation with ventricular rate in the 70s  lipids: total cholesterol 121 , triglycerides 166 , hdl 37 , ldl 51 3 , platelets 196 , 000  white blood cells 599 , hematocrit 39  bnp 659 3 , alkaline phosphatase 66  alt 26 , ast 29 , total bilirubin 0 6 , glucose 218 2 , bun 33 , creatinine 1  admission laboratory data: sodium 137 , potassium 5  his neuro exam is grossly intact , and he is alert and oriented x3  extremities are warm and well perfused with 2+ pulses and 1+ pitting edema from ankles to thighs bilaterally  his abdomen is obese , mildly tender without hepatosplenomegaly  his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally  no heave or palpable thrill  no s4 or rub  soft systolic murmur at the right lower sternal border  his heart exam is irregularly irregular with abnormal s1 and s2 , soft s3  neck shows jvp is approximately 7 cm  generally , this is a comfortable-at-rest-appearing gentleman in no respiratory distress 7 , heart rate 80 , blood pressure 144/78 , respiratory rate 20 , o2 saturation 97% on room air  admission physical examination: vitals were temperature of 95  allergies: flagyl to which he gets edema and demerol  family history: significant for brother who died of an mi at age 58 , father who died of an mi at age 78 , and mother with atherosclerosis  he does have an occasional glass of wine or two at dinnertime  he does not drink excessively  he does not smoke  he currently lives in jo car mont with his wife  tota is a retired lobbyist  social history: mr  coenzyme q10  20  folic acid  19  zinc  18  magnesium  17  vitamin b12  16  vitamin c  15  multivitamin  14  nexium 40 mg daily  13  elavil 10 mg daily  12  lantus 24 units subcutaneously daily  11 d i  glyburide/metformin 2-5/500 mg b  10  pravachol 40 mg daily  9  zetia 10 mg daily  8  aspirin 81 mg daily  7  k-dur 10 meq every monday and friday  6  lasix 20 mg every other day  5  amiodarone 200 mg daily  4 5 mg on tuesday and thursday  coumadin 5 mg on monday , wednesday , friday , saturday , and sunday; 7  3  diovan 160 mg daily  2 d i  toprol xl 50 mg b  preadmission medications: 1  he was admitted for diuresis in the setting of a chf exacerbation and for consideration of options in the treatment of his atrial fibrillation  gabard 's clinic on the day of admission for evaluation  given his worsening symptoms , he presented to dr  he was started on amiodarone on 4/13/2006 for atrial fibrillation  he endorses worsening orthopnea and pnd over the several weeks prior to admission  electrophysiology adjusted his icd , still he reports continued symptoms as previously described as well as decreased appetite and weight gain of 15 pounds over 6 weeks  consequently , ett was done on 9/15/2006 , which was terminated after 1 minute when the patient's heart rate went up to 130  he continued to feel even more unwell towards the later end of march , with episodes of nausea , diaphoresis , shortness of breath , and abdominal pain with exertion ( these were his typical angina symptoms in the past )  given his increased risk for sudden death , a single-chamber icd was placed  an echocardiogram was done in march 2006 , showing an ejection fraction of 28%  he was cardioverted in july 2006 , resulting in symptomatic improvement until march 2006 when he again reportedly felt weak , had increased dyspnea with exertion  he was found to be in atrial fibrillation and was started on coumadin , with continuation of the toprol for rate control  in august 2006 , he notes that he began to feel weak with increased dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations , although he denied any chest pain  history of present illness: this is a 77-year-old male with a history of cad , chf with an ejection fraction of 30% , atrial fibrillation ( diagnosed in 2000 , status post 4 cardioversions , on amiodarone until march 2005 , when it was discontinued due to skin discoloration; since then , the patient has been on toprol ) , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , who has done well since a stent was placed in 2002 , not requiring any hospitalizations for cardiac-related issues  hypertension  2  insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus  list of problems and diagnoses: 1  atrial fibrillation and flutter  2  chf exacerbation"
" atrial fibrillation and flutter  hypertension  history of present illness: this is a 77-year-old male with a history of cad , chf with an ejection fraction of 30% , atrial fibrillation ( diagnosed in 2000 , status post 4 cardioversions , on amiodarone until march 2005 , when it was discontinued due to skin discoloration; since then , the patient has been on toprol ) , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , who has done well since a stent was placed in 2002 , not requiring any hospitalizations for cardiac-related issues  he was started on amiodarone on 4/13/2006 for atrial fibrillation  gabard 's clinic on the day of admission for evaluation 3 , platelets 196 , 000  atrial fibrillation: given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and flutter since 2000 and his continued symptoms on toprol ( amiodarone was not an option that the patient wished to pursue given the side effects of skin discoloration that he had previously experienced )  it was decided to proceed with dofetilide therapy on 7/13/2006"
" he was found to be in atrial fibrillation and was started on coumadin , with continuation of the toprol for rate control  in august 2006 , he notes that he began to feel weak with increased dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations , although he denied any chest pain  history of present illness: this is a 77-year-old male with a history of cad , chf with an ejection fraction of 30% , atrial fibrillation ( diagnosed in 2000 , status post 4 cardioversions , on amiodarone until march 2005 , when it was discontinued due to skin discoloration; since then , the patient has been on toprol ) , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , who has done well since a stent was placed in 2002 , not requiring any hospitalizations for cardiac-related issues  hypertension  2  insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus  list of problems and diagnoses: 1  atrial fibrillation and flutter  2  chf exacerbation"
" atrial fibrillation and flutter  hypertension  history of present illness: this is a 77-year-old male with a history of cad , chf with an ejection fraction of 30% , atrial fibrillation ( diagnosed in 2000 , status post 4 cardioversions , on amiodarone until march 2005 , when it was discontinued due to skin discoloration; since then , the patient has been on toprol ) , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , who has done well since a stent was placed in 2002 , not requiring any hospitalizations for cardiac-related issues  he was started on amiodarone on 4/13/2006 for atrial fibrillation  gabard 's clinic on the day of admission for evaluation 3 , platelets 196 , 000  atrial fibrillation: given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and flutter since 2000 and his continued symptoms on toprol ( amiodarone was not an option that the patient wished to pursue given the side effects of skin discoloration that he had previously experienced )  it was decided to proceed with dofetilide therapy on 7/13/2006"
" the patient was continued on aspirin and zetia for hyperlipidemia  there were no symptoms or signs consistent with ischemia in-house  the plan was to restart his ace inhibitor following complete diuresis to dry weight  his toprol was continued in-house , but his ace inhibitor was held in the setting of increases in his serum creatinine  daily on 7/13/2006 o  he was switched over to lasix 80 mg p 5 l , and he did very well on this dose of lasix for the in and out goal  the daily goal for his was -2 to 2 6  on presentation , he was compensated for his congestive heart failure , with a creatinine of 1  congestive heart failure: the patient was started with a diuretic regimen of lasix 40 mg iv twice a day given that he appeared to be volume overloaded by clinical exam  hospital course by problem: 1  procedures: on 6/15/2006 , the patient was started on dofetilide  chest x-ray , 6/30/2006 , shows cardiomegaly with an interstitial process and without effusions  there is a dilated aortic root  mild mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation  there is a hypokinetic mid to distal wall , posterior and inferior wall  septum is thin and akinetic at the apex 8% 2%; end-systole 4  left ventricular diameter , end-diastole , 6  echocardiogram , 6/30/2006 : ejection fraction 30%  no st changes  normal intervals  ekg showed atrial fibrillation with ventricular rate in the 70s  lipids: total cholesterol 121 , triglycerides 166 , hdl 37 , ldl 51 3 , platelets 196 , 000  white blood cells 599 , hematocrit 39  bnp 659 3 , alkaline phosphatase 66  alt 26 , ast 29 , total bilirubin 0 6 , glucose 218 2 , bun 33 , creatinine 1  admission laboratory data: sodium 137 , potassium 5  his neuro exam is grossly intact , and he is alert and oriented x3  extremities are warm and well perfused with 2+ pulses and 1+ pitting edema from ankles to thighs bilaterally  his abdomen is obese , mildly tender without hepatosplenomegaly  his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally  no heave or palpable thrill  no s4 or rub  soft systolic murmur at the right lower sternal border  his heart exam is irregularly irregular with abnormal s1 and s2 , soft s3  neck shows jvp is approximately 7 cm  generally , this is a comfortable-at-rest-appearing gentleman in no respiratory distress 7 , heart rate 80 , blood pressure 144/78 , respiratory rate 20 , o2 saturation 97% on room air  admission physical examination: vitals were temperature of 95  allergies: flagyl to which he gets edema and demerol  family history: significant for brother who died of an mi at age 58 , father who died of an mi at age 78 , and mother with atherosclerosis  he does have an occasional glass of wine or two at dinnertime  he does not drink excessively  he does not smoke  he currently lives in jo car mont with his wife  tota is a retired lobbyist  social history: mr  coenzyme q10  20  folic acid  19  zinc  18  magnesium  17  vitamin b12  16  vitamin c  15  multivitamin  14  nexium 40 mg daily  13  elavil 10 mg daily  12  lantus 24 units subcutaneously daily  11 d i  glyburide/metformin 2-5/500 mg b  10  pravachol 40 mg daily  9  zetia 10 mg daily  8  aspirin 81 mg daily  7  k-dur 10 meq every monday and friday  6  lasix 20 mg every other day  5  amiodarone 200 mg daily  4 5 mg on tuesday and thursday  coumadin 5 mg on monday , wednesday , friday , saturday , and sunday; 7  3  diovan 160 mg daily  2 d i  toprol xl 50 mg b  preadmission medications: 1  he was admitted for diuresis in the setting of a chf exacerbation and for consideration of options in the treatment of his atrial fibrillation  gabard 's clinic on the day of admission for evaluation  given his worsening symptoms , he presented to dr  he was started on amiodarone on 4/13/2006 for atrial fibrillation  he endorses worsening orthopnea and pnd over the several weeks prior to admission  electrophysiology adjusted his icd , still he reports continued symptoms as previously described as well as decreased appetite and weight gain of 15 pounds over 6 weeks  consequently , ett was done on 9/15/2006 , which was terminated after 1 minute when the patient's heart rate went up to 130  he continued to feel even more unwell towards the later end of march , with episodes of nausea , diaphoresis , shortness of breath , and abdominal pain with exertion ( these were his typical angina symptoms in the past )  given his increased risk for sudden death , a single-chamber icd was placed  an echocardiogram was done in march 2006 , showing an ejection fraction of 28%  he was cardioverted in july 2006 , resulting in symptomatic improvement until march 2006 when he again reportedly felt weak , had increased dyspnea with exertion  he was found to be in atrial fibrillation and was started on coumadin , with continuation of the toprol for rate control  in august 2006 , he notes that he began to feel weak with increased dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations , although he denied any chest pain  history of present illness: this is a 77-year-old male with a history of cad , chf with an ejection fraction of 30% , atrial fibrillation ( diagnosed in 2000 , status post 4 cardioversions , on amiodarone until march 2005 , when it was discontinued due to skin discoloration; since then , the patient has been on toprol ) , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , who has done well since a stent was placed in 2002 , not requiring any hospitalizations for cardiac-related issues  hypertension  2  insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus  list of problems and diagnoses: 1  atrial fibrillation and flutter  2  chf exacerbation"

lives in jo car mont with his wife  tota is a retired lobbyist  social history: mr  coenzyme q10  20  folic acid  19  zinc  18  magnesium  17  vitamin b12  16  vitamin c  15  multivitamin  14  nexium 40 mg daily  13  elavil 10 mg daily  12  lantus 24 units subcutaneously daily  11 d i  glyburide/metformin 2-5/500 mg b  10  pravachol 40 mg daily  9  zetia 10 mg daily  8  aspirin 81 mg daily  7 7  3  diovan 160 mg daily  2 d i  toprol xl 50 mg b  preadmission medications: 1  he was admitted for diuresis in the setting of a chf exacerbation and for consideration of options in the treatment of his atrial fibrillation  gabard 's clinic on the day of admission for evaluation  given his worsening symptoms , he presented to dr  he was started on amiodarone on 4/13/2006 for atrial fibrillation  he endorses worsening orthopnea and pnd over the several weeks prior to admission  electrophysiology adjusted his icd , still he reports continued symptoms as previously described as well as decreased appetite and weight gain of 15 pounds over 6 weeks  consequently , ett was done on 9/15/2006 , which was terminated after 1 minute when the patient's heart rate went up to 130  he continued to feel even more unwell towards the later end of march , with episodes of nausea , diaphoresis , shortness of breath , and abdominal pain with exertion ( these were his typical angina symptoms in the past )  given his increased risk for sudden death , a single-chamber icd was placed  an echocardiogram was done in march 2006 , showing an ejection fraction of 28%  he was cardioverted in july 2006 , resulting in symptomatic improvement until march 2006 when he again reportedly felt weak , had increased dyspnea with exertion  he was found to be in atrial fibrillation and was started on coumadin , with continuation of the toprol for rate control  in august 2006 , he notes that he began to feel weak with increased dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations , although he denied any chest pain  history of present illness: this is a 77-year-old male with a history of cad , chf with an ejection fraction of 30% , atrial fibrillation ( diagnosed in 2000 , status post 4 cardioversions , on amiodarone until march 2005 , when it was discontinued due to skin discoloration; since then , the patient has been on toprol ) , insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , who has done well since a stent was placed in 2002 , not requiring any hospitalizations for cardiac-related issues  hypertension  2  insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus  list of problems and diagnoses: 1  atrial fibrillation and flutter  2  chf exacerbation"

"  the day before discharge , she had a chest x-ray and a question of pneumonia , so she was started on levofloxacin and attending surgeon , dr  the discharge decision was made on 9/1/03   she is ambulating very well and food intake is okay  no evidence of any pneumothorax  her chest tubes were pulled out  her epicardial pacing wires were pulled out  on the floor , she was started on her cardiac meds  she was slowly weaned from oxygen and she was transferred to the floor in stable condition on postoperative day #2  later , she underwent gentle diuresis  initially , she had volume infusion to stabilize hemodynamics  immediately after surgery she was taken to the cardiac surgical icu , where she was extubated and the blood gases were appropriate  procedure was a posterior lateral thoracotomy , automatic implanted cardioverter defibrillator  postoperative diagnosis was epicardial lead placed   preoperative diagnosis was a failed coronary sinus lead  hospital course: she was taken to the operating room on 5/9/03   ekg , 0/29/03 , paced rhythm at 68  echo was done on 0/4 - 10% ejection fraction , trivial aortic insufficiency , severe mitral insufficiency  urinalysis normal 8 2 , ptt 29 1 , inr 1  pt 15 6 , platelets 219 3 , hemoglobin 13 43 , hematocrit 39  wbc 7 1 0 , glucose 109 , magnesium 2 9 , chloride 105 , carbon dioxide 24 , bun 17 , serum creatinine 1 abdomen is on the right upper quadrant  abdomen: soft , no masses  respiratory: breath sounds clear bilaterally  pulses: carotid 2+ , radial 2+ , femoral 2+ , dorsalis pedis 2+ , posterior tibialis 2+ bilaterally  cardiovascular: regular rate and rhythm , no murmurs  chest: no incisions  heent: dentition without evidence of infection , no carotid bruits  physical examination: vital signs: height 5 feet 5 inches , weight 95 kg , temperature 98 , heart rate 68 , blood pressure 104/60 d  , vitamin e 400 u q d  , centrum q m  , xanax 5 mg five times daily , lantus 48 u p d 625 mg q  , premarin 0 d carvedilol 25 mg p   allergies: no known drug allergies  the last one 4/28/03   social history: history of tobacco use , three pack cigarette-smoking history , history of alcohol use , remote , heavy , and now three beers per month  father had mi  family history: coronary artery disease significant  past surgical history: status post appendectomy , status post cholecystectomy , and hysterectomy  past medical history: hypertension , diabetes mellitus , insulin therapy , hypercholesterolemia , recurrent bronchitis , agoraphobia , panic attacks  previous cardiovascular interventions: status post icd pacer placement  the patient is in paced rhythm  preoperative cardiac status: a history of class iii heart failure , marked limitation of physical activity , recent signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure , including paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea , dyspnea on exertion , pedal edema  request new pacer lead placement via left thoracotomy  the patient now presents with shortness of breath at minimal activity with fatigue and occasional paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  lead dislodged in may 2002 as the patient was wallpapering , and it was replaced suboptimally  she has been medically managed since then , and in july 2002 , required a permanent pacer icd to prevent vt in the setting of ejection fraction of 10%  at 51 , the patient developed a viral cardiomyopathy with resulting cardiomyopathy  history of present illness: she had developed a left bundle branch block at age 40  larbi is a 62-year-old female who came to the s medical center for evaluation of her cardiomyopathy and pacer placement  ventricular lead | signed | dis | admission date: 2/25/2003 report status: signed  discharge date: 9/0/2003 identification: mrs"

carvedilol 25 mg p   allergies: no known drug allergies  the last one 4/28/03   social history: history of tobacco use , three pack cigarette-smoking history , history of alcohol use , remote , heavy , and now three beers per month  father had mi  family history: coronary artery disease significant  past surgical history: status post appendectomy , status post cholecystectomy , and hysterectomy  past medical history: hypertension , diabetes mellitus , insulin therapy , hypercholesterolemia , recurrent bronchitis , agoraphobia , panic attacks  previous cardiovascular interventions: status post icd pacer placement  the patient is in paced rhythm  preoperative cardiac status: a history of class iii heart failure , marked limitation of physical activity , recent signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure , including paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea , dyspnea on exertion , pedal edema  request new pacer lead placement via left thoracotomy  the patient now presents with shortness of breath at minimal activity with fatigue and occasional paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  lead dislodged in may 2002 as the patient was wallpapering , and it was replaced suboptimally  she has been " she was awake and appeared comfortable on fentanyl for analgesia  on postoperative day 1 , the patient remained in the intensive care unit  she was on triple antibiotics for full coverage and treatment of her infection  she was started on neofed for control of her blood pressure to get it to the 70s , and was receiving metoprolol and esmolol for a heart rate that had gone up to the 130s  postoperatively , the patient remained intubated and was in the surgical intensive care unit  hospital course: patient was taken emergently to the operating room for an incision and drainage of this abscess , which was believed to be a necrotizing fasciitis  the ua showed some trace blood and trace leukocyte esterase  ekg on admission showed sinus tachycardia , with some t wave inversion , and chest x-ray showed some mild pulmonary edema 4  white blood cell count of 18 8 , and a glucose of 357  labs on admission: bun of 73 , creatinine of 3  there was no labial or perirectal involvement  her extremities showed a large right thigh abscess with a boil immediately below the pannus , with positive erythema , tenderness down to the knee and up to the groin  rectal exam was trace guaiac-positive by report  her abdomen was soft and obese , nontender , with audible but low bowel sounds  her lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally  she had a 2/6 systolic murmur louder on the right  cardiovascularly , she was tachycardic and regular  she was generally a mildly ill appearing obese female 5 , her heart rate was 128 , blood pressure 103/52 , and she was breathing regularly , saturating 98% on room air  physical exam on admission: in the emergency department here at the merso ri riska hospital , her temperature was 101  allergies: allergies include penicillin  medications: her home medications include glyburide , metformin , hydrochlorothiazide , protonix , lipitor , and zestril  past medical history: past medical history includes insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , morbid obesity , critical as , hypertension , hypercholesterolemia , and anemia  her glucose had become difficult to control since the start of the abscess , and she presented to the emergency department tachycardic and hypotensive  the patient was unable to ambulate secondary to this abscess pain , patient with chills and fevers to 102  history of present illness: this is a 73-year-old female with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and critical as , who presented to the emergency department from her primary care er/ neslath community hospital of office presenting with a right thigh mass present x 4 days"

" she was recently admitted here on august for the same complaint treated with iv levofloxacin and clindamycin for five days and then went home on ten days of dicloxacillin , then keflex  at home she was able to ambulate , but had significant pain localizing to her left foot and toe  she denies any fever , chills , cough , shortness of breath , nausea , or vomiting  the patient reported having her podiatrist clip her nails about two months ago which is when her pain in her foot started  history of present illness: this is an 89-year-old woman with insulin dependent diabetes , coronary artery disease , hypertension , peripheral vascular disease , and ejection fraction of 28% who had a left fem-peroneal bypass in the past presented with on-going left toe pain admitted for left toe vascular insufficiency and cellulitis refractory to treatment for two months  other diagnoses: diabetes mellitus , known vascular disease , incontinence , recurrent utis , hypertension   principal problem: vascular insufficiency"

enteric-coated aspirin 325 mg p  she had no further problems with arrhythmia and the remainder of her postoperative course was uncomplicated  she was successfully weaned off oxygen on postoperative day #6 , she was noted on that same day to have had 10 beats of vt which was pointed out to cardiology and her beta-blocker was increased  she required intravenous lasix to return to her preoperative weight  the patient was slow to ambulate and needed encouragement  she was followed by cardiology during the postoperative period as well as the diabetes management service for blood sugar control was taken to the intensive care unit following surgery in stable condition  intraoperative findings included calcified lad   because of her diffuse arthropathy and jehovah's witness status , it was woman with a history of diabetes mellitus , obesity , and hyperlipidemia as well as peripheral vascular disease who has had progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion"

" postoperatively the patient was maintained on coumadin for deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis  she had her wound inspected on postoperative day #2 and thereafter her incision remained clean , dry , and intact without any evidence of erythema or drainage i  followup: the patient will follow-up with dr  an old mri scan also shows these osteonecrotic changes in the right femoral head  the patient did quite well with this and her paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia resolved  she worked with physical therapy on a daily basis and progressed well once her heart rate was under control  her incision appeared clean , dry , and intact without any evidence of infection  abdomen: soft , nontender , nondistended  the patient was then placed on lopressor 25 mg b  the patient was ruled out for a myocardial infarction and her ck and mb remained negative  she had resolution of her paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia with heart rate down into the 80s and 90s on lopressor 25 mg b  she has dentures  a medicine consult was obtained and it was recommended that she be placed on verapamil 80 mg t d  as mentioned previously the patient was maintained on coumadin for deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis  allergies: no known drug allergies  she received one unit of autologous blood for a postoperative hematocrit of 29 on postoperative day #1 d  she was able to progress with physical therapy without any episodes of increase in heart rate 125 mg p   she underwent a right total hip replacement 4 i 5 mg b  she has a 30 degree straight leg raise , 90 degrees of flexion , 10 degrees of internal rotation , 30 degrees of external rotation , and 2+ dorsalis pedis pulse  postoperatively the patient was maintained on coumadin for deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis i  b  heart: regular rate and rhythm  an old mri scan also shows these osteonecrotic changes in the right femoral head  she did not require any further transfusions and the last hematocrit prior to discharge was 35 i  no lymphadenopathy  abdomen: soft , nontender , nondistended  the details of this procedure can be seen in the operative note d  q  she has dentures  laboratory data: x-rays demonstrated collapse of the right femoral head consistent with osteonecrosis on the right  past medical history: degenerative joint disease bilateral hands d  allergies: no known drug allergies  infrequent ectopic beats  hip | signed | dis | admission date: 2/25/1997 report status: signed  discharge date: 2/26/1997 final diagnosis: ( 1 ) osteonecrosis of right hip ( 2 ) paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia procedure: right total hip replacement history of present illness: the patient is a 73 year old female who developed new onset of right sided hip pain approximately four months ago"
" she had a pca for pain control and this was quite adequate  postoperatively the patient was maintained on coumadin for deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis  the details of this procedure can be seen in the operative note   she underwent a right total hip replacement  hospital course: the patient was taken to the operating room on 4/5/97   an old mri scan also shows these osteonecrotic changes in the right femoral head  laboratory data: x-rays demonstrated collapse of the right femoral head consistent with osteonecrosis on the right  she has a 30 degree straight leg raise , 90 degrees of " it was felt that an acute myocardial infarction was less likely and it was felt that pulmonary edema was secondary to his hypertensive disease being out of control  his electrophoresis came back negative  the patient was stable overnight  the patient's third set cpk came back at 429 with 10 mb's  he was given iv lasix for diuresis and magnesium  he was also started on lopressor  the patient was treated with nitroglycerin , heparin and aspirin  the patient had decreased blood pressure and heart rate and was treated with narcan and atropine  the patient developed left arm pain with inflation and slow flow after ptca  the patient underwent cardiac catheterization which revealed pulmonary capillary wedge of 30 , rv 46/14 , pa 46/30 , ramus occluded 50%  this was new compared with prior ekg  there was st elevation of 1-2 mm in v1-3 , t wave inversion in i , l , v4-6; q's in v1 and v2  there were left atrial abnormalities  hospital course: ekg showed normal sinus rhythm at 91 , -15 degrees axis  blood pressure dropped to 99/67 with treatment and he was sent for emergent cardiac catheterization  ekg showed q's in v1-2 , 1-2 mm st increasing in v1 , lateral t wave inversions  he was also given lopressor , 15 mg  he was treated with nitroglycerin , morphine , lasix and nitropaste  in the emergency room he had a blood pressure of 207/150 with saturation of 93% , rales and positive s4  he was seen at higheun medical center because he was \"unable to breathe\"  on the day of admission after taking a shower in the morning , he had increasing shortness of breath gradually at rest with epigastric tightness without radiation but he did have nausea , vomiting and diaphoresis  he had no chest pain but did have diaphoresis and mild nausea and vomiting as well as lightheadedness and some palpitations lasting approximately one hour in duration  he had a head cold with congestion and cough at that time  two weeks prior to admission , the patient walked one block , he had acute shortness of breath while awaiting for a train  he exercises daily as well as jogging  he had an exercise tolerance test one day later without chest pain or shortness of breath  he was admitted to ach for question of rule out myocardial infarction  approximately one year ago , he was sitting on a bike awaiting an exercise test and he felt lightheaded without any chest pain  zirker for hypertension  the patient is followed by dr  his cardiac risk factors include a history of cigarette smoking , hypertension , family history , questionable history of hypercholesterolemia and no history of diabetes"

" atrial fibrillation  on presentation on this admission , he did not have a history of angina , but did have a history of class iii heart failure with marked limitation of physical activity  the neosynephrine was the first drip to be discontinued and the patient remained on milrinone and epinephrine  he was started on an afterload reducing agent , first a drip of sodium nitroprusside , after he had had a trial of esmolol  he remained in atrial fibrillation and did not convert to sinus  transesophageal echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 30% and no clots in the atrial ventricles  transesophageal echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 30% and no clots in the atrial ventricles  he was on subcutaneous insulin and his sugars were well controlled"
" on transfer to the floor , he remains on argatroban with a goal ptt of 50 to 70 and he is getting coumadin with goal inr 2 to 3  he was started on argatroban and bridged to coumadin  he did have a marked drop in his platelets and was positive for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia  heme: the patient was anticoagulated with heparin initially for the intraaortic balloon pump and atrial fibrillation cannula and he was able to ambulate and get out of bed  pulmonary: initially , the patient required bipap while in the intensive care unit  3  his pulmonary artery catheter was discontinued prior to atrial fibrillation on transfer to the floor  he remained in a sinus rhythm for approximately three days until postoperative day 11 when he switched back into atrial fibrillation that was refractory to ibutilide  transesophageal echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 30% and no clots in the atrial ventricles  on postoperative day 8 , he was taken to the operating room and cardioverted successfully to sinus rhythm  he remained in atrial fibrillation and did not convert to sinus  his rate did improve  he was loaded with amiodarone in spite of his prior history of pulmonary and hepatic toxicity with plan to use a short course of amiodarone to improve the rate  he was given trial of ibutilide , which did not significantly change his rate or convert him into sinus rhythm  his rapid atrial fibrillation remained refractory to medical treatment  he did seem to have improvement with the afterload reducing agent of sodium nitroprusside  the esmolol did improve his rates slightly but did not significantly improve his cardiac output or his mixed venous oxygen saturation  he was started on an afterload reducing agent , first a drip of sodium nitroprusside , after he had had a trial of esmolol  slowly the drips were weaned  the intraaortic balloon pump remained in until postoperative day# 9 when it was discontinued  postoperatively , he had an intraaortic balloon pump  he continued to have marginal mixed venous oxygen saturation and poor cardiac performance as assessed by cardiac output and cardiac index  he was in rapid atrial fibrillation and was initially loaded with digoxin , which did improve the rate transiently  both of these were slowly weaned , the epinephrine coming off first and the milrinone coming off two days prior to transfer out of the icu  the neosynephrine was the first drip to be discontinued and the patient remained on milrinone and epinephrine  the milrinone was initially given a weaning trial , but his mixed venous oxygen saturations dropped to the high 40s and low 50s and the milrinone was restarted  cardiovascular: the patient was brought to the icu on neosynephrine , epinephrine and milrinone drips  2  he was neurologically intact throughout the course of his icu stay and he was transferred to floor with no focal deficits , moving all extremities and pain that is well controlled d i 5 mg b  he also was continued on his own dose of clonazepam 2  morphine n r s and p o  this was transitioned over to motrin and he was taking p  toradol n r  the patient's pain was well controlled with p  sedation was weaned and he was extubated without incident  he was adequately sedated  neurologic: the patient was brought to the intensive care unit from the operating room on a propofol drip  icu course: 1  the cross-clamp time was 98 minutes  the bypass time was 257 minutes  operation procedures: on 7/14/06 , the patient underwent a mitral valve repair with an alfieri suture , a cabg x3 with a y-graft saphenous vein; svg2 connects svg1 to lvb1 , svg1 connects to aorta to om1 , svg3 to ramus , a left ventricular aneurysm repair and epicardial lead placement  laboratory data on admission: an echocardiogram performed at the beauton geson health care services on 8/2/06 showed an ejection fraction of 25% with mild mitral insufficiency , mild tricuspid insufficiency and an aicd wire in the right heart  his extremities were without scaring or edema and he did not have varicosities present  there were no masses and the abdomen was soft and nontender  his abdomen was notable for scars from a previous right cholecystectomy and a left lower quadrant incision for placement of icd  his breath sounds were clear and equal bilaterally  no murmurs were appreciated  examination of the chest was notable for a "record #63337 697377829 | neh | 38527267 | | 2945162 | 4/3/2007 12:00:00 am | partial small bowel obstruction , pneumonia , chf | | dis | admission date: 5/18/2007 report status: discharge date: 0/28/2007 ****** final discharge orders ****** megraw , jamie b 935-52-49-9 rock simin burg service: med discharge patient on: 7/7/07 at 02:00 pm contingent upon not applicable will d/c order be used as the d/c summary: no ( see an addendum ) attending: robichard , doyle j , m r  ) none brief resume of hospital course: see dictation brief resume of hospital course addendum 1: cc: abdominal pain hpi: this is an 86 year-old woman with a history of chf , chronic kidney disease , diabetes , afib on cuomadin , rheumatic heart disease s/p mvr/tvr , and history of partial sbo , and a recent admission in 1/10 for abdominal pain and bilateral aspiration pneumonia who presented with abdominal pain for 36 hours  unchanged cardiomegaly  no change in bilateral lower lobe pneumonias  - gi: admitted with partial sbo  with treatment of the pneumonia and chf she was no longer hypoxic or sob  the insulin was titrated up for better glucose control to lantus 12 units daily , novolog 7 units qac , and novolog sliding scale  - id: treatment for aspiration pneumonia as above with levofloxacin and flagyl  chf: she will continue to take the lasix  pneumonia: patient will complete an 8-day course of levo and flagyl  2"
" pneumonia: she will be discharged on levofloxacin and flagyl to treat her pneumonia to complete an 8-day course , which will end on 3/18 2  ( ti879 ) on 10/1/07 @ 02:54 pm additional comments: 1 d  , m  - code: full - addended bjorseth , rosario d  hermes ( geriatrics ) at 6/11 at 2pm at mawe tesparks in hospital   new pcp is dr  the daughter is a nurse  patient and daughter prefer patient to go home w/ services  - disposition: pt recommended rehab  diet recommendations were ground diet ( for lack of teech ) and thin liquids  inr will be followed and coumadin adjusted as an outpatient - nutrition: she had a radiologic swallowing evaluation which showed deep laryngeal penetration with thin and nectar-thick liquid with no aspiration and a tiny zenker diverticulum  coumadin restarted on 0/7 at a lower dose  as above , her inr remained high off coumadin , likely due to the antibiotics  - heme: hct at baseline  ucx with mixed flora  - id: treatment for aspiration pneumonia as above with levofloxacin and flagyl 2  hba1c 8  the daughter is a nurse and will monitor and adjust her insulin at home  the insulin was titrated up for better glucose control to lantus 12 units daily , novolog 7 units qac , and novolog sliding scale  her fingersticks continued to be high , perhaps due to pneumonia  when her sbo resolved and she was eating again , her home regimen of lantus 100 units daily , novolog 5 units qac , and novolog sliding scale was restarted  - diabetes: her insulin was initially held on admission due to npo for the sbo  she continued home sevelamer 3 on discharge 6 on admission and 2  her cr was 2 8 6-2  - renal: she has a history of ckd with cr baseline of 2  she will continue levofloxacin and flagyl for an 8-day course  with treatment of the pneumonia and chf she was no longer hypoxic or sob  she was afebrile  her wbc was elevated on admission and decreased during hospitalization  she was treated with levo and flagyl  the abd ct showed bilateral lower lobe pna , likely aspiration  - pulmonary: she has a history of aspiration pna  her inr will be followed and coumadin adjusted as an outpatient  the coumadin was restarted on 0/7 as the inr was trending down , and was started at lower dose ( 2mg instead of 3mg ) given the antibiotics  the inr remained in 2-3 range , likely due to the antibiotics  the coumadin was initially held due to possible procedures related to the sbo  her rate was adequately controlled  she also has a history of afib , now on coumadin  she has a history of hypertension and was continued on norvasc and imdur  she no longer required supplemental oxygen  overall her sob and hypoxia improved  repeat cxr on 6/18 looks a little better than admission  she was initially given lasix 80mg bid which required additional doses of lasix iv prn to diurese , so the dose was increased to 160mg po bid  she is on variable doses of lasix ( 80-200mg po bid ) at home  she was not agressively diuresed in the setting of the partial sbo  she reported sob prior to admission which ws thought to be due to a chf exacerbation  echo 0/0 with ef 45-50% , no rwma , mod lae and rae , bioprosthetic mv w/ tr mr , tr ar , severe tr , mild-mod pr  - cv: she has a history of diastolic dysfunction  the sbo resolved and she was passing stool and tolerating a normal diet  no ngt was required  she was treated wtih conservative management  - gi: administer iron products a minimum of 2 hours before or after a levofloxacin or ciprofloxacin dose dose if on tube feeds , please cycle ( hold 1 hr before to 2 hr after ) take 2 hours before or 2 hours after dairy products  thanks  if ordered hs administer alone insulin aspart 7 units sc ac hold if: npo lantus ( insulin glargine ) 12 units sc qpm instructions: give 1/2 dose if npo imdur er ( isosorbide mononitrate ( sr ) ) 30 mg po bid hold if: sbp &lt; 100 instructions: do not crush imdur  ) 5 , 000 units sc qweek instructions: on tuesday ferrous sulfate 325 mg po bid food/drug interaction instruction avoid milk and antacid lasix ( furosemide ) 160 mg po bid hold if: sbp&lt;100 insulin aspart sliding scale ( subcutaneously ) sc ac+hs low scale call ho if bs less than 60 if bs is less than 125 , then do not administer supplemental ( sliding scale ) insulin if bs is 125-150 , then give 0 units subcutaneously if bs is 151-200 , then give 1 units subcutaneously if bs is 201-250 , then give 2 units subcutaneously if bs is 251-300 , then give 3 units subcutaneously if bs is 301-350 , then give 4 units subcutaneously if bs is 351-400 , then give 5 units subcutaneously call ho if bs is greater than 350 if ordered qac administer at same time as , and in addition to , standing insulin aspart order    calcium carbonate 1 , 500 mg ( 600 mg elem ca )/ vit d 200 iu 1 tab po bid procrit ( non-oncology ) ( epoetin alfa ( non-onc 5 mg qpm instructions: crushed meds food/drug interaction instruction avoid grapefruit unless md instructs otherwise 5 mg qpm po 5 mg qam 2 " pneumonia: she will be discharged on levofloxacin and flagyl to treat her pneumonia to complete an 8-day course , which will end on 3/18 2  ( ti879 ) on 10/1/07 @ 02:54 pm additional comments: 1 d  , m  - code: full - addended bjorseth , rosario d  hermes ( geriatrics ) at 6/11 at 2pm at mawe tesparks in hospital   new pcp is dr  the daughter is a nurse  patient and daughter prefer patient to go home w/ services  - disposition: pt recommended rehab  diet recommendations were ground diet ( for lack of teech ) and thin liquids  inr will be followed and coumadin adjusted as an outpatient - nutrition: she had a radiologic swallowing evaluation which showed deep laryngeal penetration with thin and nectar-thick liquid with no aspiration and a tiny zenker diverticulum  coumadin restarted on 0/7 at a lower dose  as above , her inr remained high off coumadin , likely due to the antibiotics  - heme: hct at baseline  ucx with mixed flora  - id: treatment for aspiration pneumonia as above with levofloxacin and flagyl 2  hba1c 8  the daughter is a nurse and will monitor and adjust her insulin at home  the insulin was titrated up for better glucose control to lantus 12 units daily , novolog 7 units qac , and novolog sliding scale  her fingersticks continued to be high , perhaps due to pneumonia  when her sbo resolved and she was eating again , her home regimen of lantus 100 units daily , novolog 5 units qac , and novolog sliding scale was restarted  - diabetes: her insulin was initially held on admission due to npo for the sbo  she continued home sevelamer 3 on discharge 6 on admission and 2  her cr was 2 8 6-2  - renal: she has a history of ckd with cr baseline of 2  she will continue levofloxacin and flagyl for an 8-day course  with treatment of the pneumonia and chf she was no longer hypoxic or sob  she was afebrile  her wbc was elevated on admission and decreased during hospitalization  she was treated with levo and flagyl  the abd ct showed bilateral lower lobe pna , likely aspiration  - pulmonary: she has a history of aspiration pna  her inr will be followed and coumadin adjusted as an outpatient  the coumadin was restarted on 0/7 as the inr was trending down , and was started at lower dose ( 2mg instead of 3mg ) given the antibiotics  the inr remained in 2-3 range , likely due to the antibiotics  the coumadin was initially held due to possible procedures related to the sbo  her rate was adequately controlled  she also has a history of afib , now on coumadin  she has a history of hypertension and was continued on norvasc and imdur  she no longer required supplemental oxygen  overall her sob and hypoxia improved  repeat cxr on 6/18 looks a little better than admission  she was initially given lasix 80mg bid which required additional doses of lasix iv prn to diurese , so the dose was increased to 160mg po bid  she is on variable doses of lasix ( 80-200mg po bid ) at home  she was not agressively diuresed in the setting of the partial sbo  she reported sob prior to admission which ws thought to be due to a chf exacerbation  echo 0/0 with ef 45-50% , no rwma , mod lae and rae , bioprosthetic mv w/ tr mr , tr ar , severe tr , mild-mod pr  - cv: she has a history of diastolic dysfunction  the sbo resolved and she was passing stool and tolerating a normal diet  no ngt was required  she was treated wtih conservative management  - gi: admitted with partial sbo  ***** procedures: none consultants: none ***** hospital course: this is a 86f with hx chf , afib , ckd , and diabetes who was admitted with partial sbo , bilateral " past medical history: coronary artery disease , chf , echo in august of 1999 shows moderate left ventricular hypertrophy of about 65% , diabetes type 2 20 years including with retinopathy , nephropathy and neuropathic pain , hypertension for the past 20 years , hypercholesterolemia , status post medullary cva august 1999 , right pica resulting wallenberg's syndrome , morbid obesity , left knee degenerative joint disease , iron-deficiency anemia n  a fistulogram and angioplasty of her right av fistula was performed on 9/14/06 with prednisone premedication but it was unsuccessful and therefore a left ij tunneled dialysis catheter was inserted on 10/18/06 with the tip ending in the right atrium  p  of note , she was recently hospitalized at somver vasky university of medical center on 1/5/06 through 11/11/07 for initiation of dialysis after her bun and creatinine had risen remarkably from baseline  q  in the ed , a portable chest x-ray revealed diffuse bilateral opacities , risk of pulmonary edema and abg showed respiratory acidosis  , tramadol 25 mg p  the patient then reportedly went into vfib and was shocked once by ems , resulting in a narrow qrs complex rhythm i  discharge diagnosis: sepsis/line infection , end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis o d"
" from a gi perspective the patient had a history of colonic polyps but tolerated the aspirin and was put on nexium prophylaxis  for fourteen days d  the patient did have a retrocardiac infiltrate on chest x-ray and the patient was treated with levofloxacin 500 mg q  the fev1 was 69% predicted , tlc was 63% predicted , with a dlco of 56% predicted  pfcs revealed a restrictive physiology and poor diffusion consistent with ipf  from a pulmonary standpoint the patient had lenis which were negative for a deep venous thrombosis  there was similar mild mitral regurgitation with the elliptic ring , the left atrial size was slightly increased and there was no evidence of any effusion  there was thickened aortic leaflets with trivial central insufficiency and no evidence of any outflow tract obstruction  there was trivial to 1+ tricuspid regurgitation with right heart pressures within normal limits  there was stromal mild right ventricular hypertrophy and overall right heart function appeared to be preserved  there was left ventricular hypertrophy  there was no discrete evidence of wall motion abnormality although the inferior and posterior segments were not well visualized  the ejection fraction was found to be 55%  the echo showed preserved left ventricular function with a good ejection fraction  , with ambulation e  the patient remained chest pain free and had no chest pain on exertion , i  the patient underwent ptca and stent x 2 with good results  the patient underwent cardiac catheterization which revealed lad ostial 90% , proximal 80% , diag ostial 90% , left circ 90% , 80% lesions , marginal 1 , tub 90% , rca 50%  and was ruled out for enzymes d  , heparin , oxygen and hooked up to a cardiac monitor and ekg q d i 5 t  the patient was initially put on aspirin , lopressor 37  from a cardiovascular standpoint the patient has known coronary artery disease with ekg changes which is likely status post non-q-wave myocardial infarction with a question of continued unstable angina  the differential diagnosis included unstable angina and pe with worsening ipf superimposed on heart disease 19  of note her troponin was 0  hospital course: this is a 65-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease , hypertension , diabetes , ipf who presented with five days of chest pain/sob beginning with sudden onset five days prior to admission and had ekg changes consistent with a non-q-wave myocardial infarction anterolaterally  chest x-ray: positive for mild pulmonary edema , retrocardial infiltrate and left effusion  1/17 adenosine mibi: no , tp 7 6 , chloride/bicarb 109/19 , bun/creatinine 20/1 2 platelets 408 , sodium 138 , potassium 5 44 , hematocrit 34  laboratory data: white count 8  sensation intact distally  dtrs 2+  neuro: alert and oriented x 3  extremities: trace pedal edema  abdomen: obese , soft , nontender , positive bowel sounds  cardiovascular: distant heart sounds , regular rate and rhythm , normal s1s2 , no murmurs , rubs or gallops  no wheezes , no focal dullness  pulmonary: dry , fine crackles one-third of the way up bilaterally  neck: jvp around 8 cm , no carotid bruits  eomi , perrla  heent: nc/at  general: mother died of myocardial infarction at age 73  bactrim , also hives  allergies: iv contrast , patient gets hives d ; atenolol 50 mg q m  p  and 40 q m  a ; insulin 70/30 90 q d i ; axid 150 mg b d i ; lopid 600 mg b d ; lasix 40 mg q d i  medications on admission: captopril 50 mg b  past medical history: insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus x 30 years , hypertension , ipf diagnosed in 1986 treated with digoxin and prednisone , osteoarthritis , obesity , pneumonia , colonic polyps with guaiac-positive stool , tkr on 9/24 , cholecystectomy , bell's palsy x 20 years , lbp , right cataracts , catheterization in 1998 showed a lad lesion of 40% and a circ lesion of 30% , rca lesion of 30% 19 and was thus admitted to the cardiology memp mont service  the patient presented to her primary care physician today secondary to continued shortness of breath and was sent to the emergency department where electrocardiogram revealed some st depressions anterolaterally with a troponin leak with a troponin level of 0  the patient has had stable two-pillow orthopnea and notes no weight gain or loss , but notes decreased exercise tolerance over the past month  the patient did complain of some bilateral foot edema 1-2 weeks prior to admission  she denied any fever , chills , uri symptoms , cough , change in bowel movements  she also noted diaphoresis with all those episodes  the patient did continue to have increased shortness of breath at rest and worsened dyspnea on exertion with around two episodes per day of severe chest pressure/dyspnea/pain that required her to remain still over the next five days  the patient did have some nausea and vomiting associated with her symptoms and was most comfortable sitting up  the patient described the substernal chest pressure as being like hit in the chest and this lasted about fifteen minutes  this occurred over the next several days e , crossing the room  the patient first experienced a sudden onset of substernal chest pressure and severe shortness of breath five days prior to admission which resolved in one hour but continued to have some substernal chest pain and dyspnea on exertion with even mild exertion , i  history of present illness: this is a 65-year-old woman with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus , htn , ipf and some cad who presents with the first episode of chest pain and shortness of breath"

hypoglycemia which was then treated with prednisone overnight for iv contrast dye allergy  the origin of the hypokalemia was unclear  the patient was treated with insulin , given calcium and treated with kayexalate x 3 and the hypokalemia quickly resolved  the patient was hypokalemic on 10/23 with a curious whitening on ekg and peak t waves  from a gi perspective the patient had a history of colonic polyps but tolerated the aspirin and was put on nexium prophylaxis  for fourteen days d  the patient did have a retrocardiac infiltrate on chest x-ray and the patient was treated with increased and there was no evidence of any effusion  there was thickened aortic leaflets with trivial central insufficiency and no evidence of any outflow tract obstruction  there was trivial to 1+ tricuspid regurgitation with right heart pressures within normal limits  there was stromal mild right ventricular hypertrophy and overall right heart function appeared to be preserved  there was left
