systolic crescendo murmur and decrescendo murmur at the right upper sternal border radiating to the clavicles and carotids , and 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla , and an apical heave  admission physical examination: notable for heart rate of 94 , blood pressure of 80-90/50  on presentation , the patient was found to be hypotensive , in septic shock , with bacteremia in urinary tract infection and admitted to the medical icu for pressure support  no vomiting , diarrhea , cough , or dysuria  history of present illness: the patient is a 76-year-old with a history of severe mitral regurgitation , history of congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 60% in 7/24 , chronic abdominal discomfort , history of recurrent utis , and uterine prolapse , who one week prior to admission developed increased nausea , decreased appetite , weakness , fatigue and increased low back pain  secondary diagnoses: mitral regurgitation , diabetes , hypertension , congestive heart failure , recurrent utis , uterine prolapse , hyperlipidemia , hiatal hernia , right breast nodule"
" the patient has not been restarted on her home lasix and lisinopril secondary to persistently low blood pressures between the 90s and 100s  daily , lipitor 10 mg daily , and protonix 40 mg daily o patient had a normal random cortisol level of 35  4  she has a microcytic anemia with an mcv of 79 , her iron studies ( iron of 10 , tibc of 191 , ferritin is 744 ) suggesting anemia of chronic disease with possibly overlying iron deficiency  heme: the patient had guaiac positive stools in the medical icu , her hematocrit was stable around 33%  she was continued on nexium for prophylaxis ultrasound confirmed the ct findings  non-contrast ct of the abdomen showed biliary sludge and gallstones , no evidence of acute cholecystitis  lipitor was held , and was started as a transaminitis ventricular tachycardia  the patient also has a very severe mitral regurgitation , which would be one of the reasons that an ace on her medication regimen would be beneficial  it is anticipated that her cardiologist and outpatient physicians will attempt to add the ace back onto her medical regimen for better afterload reduction as her blood pressure tolerates  because her systolic blood pressure continued to be low in the 90s and low 100s , attempt was not made to re-add the ace while in the hospital  her lasix and ace-i were held while she was hypotensive  she has a very attenuatus balance between preload dependence and overload   she had an episode of flash pulmonary edema on 11/9 in the setting of fluid bolus and one unit of packed red blood cells   she had hypotension , requiring increased nausea , decreased appetite , weakness , fatigue and increased low back pain  secondary diagnoses: mitral regurgitation , diabetes , hypertension , congestive heart failure , recurrent utis " history of present illness: the patient is a 62-year-old man with coronary artery disease status post recent bare metal stenting in november , hypercholesterolemia , cll and peripheral arterial disease and admitted for increasing right thigh pain and falling hematocrit at rehabilitation  he does note some pain on his right side , particularly his right upper thigh and gluteal area  he felt some weakness in his right leg but has had no paresthesias or pain  pain"
" he was found to have right gluteal hematoma which was responsible for his acute hematocrit drop  the patient was admitted in november and was known to have three-vessel coronary disease and had underwent stenting of his lad with a bare metal stent on 7/15/06  right gluteal hematoma  2  impression: this is a 62-year-old man admitted for a falling hematocrit with an evolving right gluteal hematoma secondary to supratherapeutic anticoagulation  given that he had been anticoagulated due to right upper extremity dvt and that the indication for anticoagulation in the setting and catheter associated clot is somewhat murky , it was felt that the patient would not benefit from addition of anticoagulation and therefore his lovenox and coumadin were discontinued  he had an mri of his brain done on 6/21/06 which showed subacute infarction on the right anterior internal capsule and chronic occlusion of the left internal carotid and old left parietal stroke  he was also transfused a total of 6 units of prbcs for a goal hematocrit of 30 given his cardiac and neurologic disease as described below 1 , hematocrit of 22  his coumadin , lovenox , aspirin , and plavix were initially held creatinine was 2  given the ct of his abdomen without contrast that showed a suprapubic catheter obstruction with bilateral hydronephrosis and distended bladder  his inr was found to be elevated  he had a chest x-ray that showed no obvious infiltrate  he received a head ct without contrast that showed no acute bleeding or acute infarction  he received 1 liter of iv fluid  he became hypotensive with intubation despite using etomidate with blood pressures in the 60's/40's , and an initial cvp of 16 , so he was started on levophed with a systolic blood pressure in the 130's on 7 to 10 of levophed  he was therefore intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure 37/43/77 on 100% nonrebreather  he was placed on 100% nonrebreather with some improvement of his saturations in the low 90's and an abg of 7  his initial room air saturation was in the high 60's to low 70's  in the emergency room , he was found to be unresponsive , grunting , and in respiratory distress  he also was noted to have a decreased urine output from his chronic suprapubic catheter x2 days  his wife also noted him to have increasing lethargy and decreased responsiveness and called ems to have him brought to the emergency room  despite being placed on the machine , he was still having air hunger and complaining of feeling unwell  he was doing well until the morning of 1/22/2006 when he complained of difficulty breathing and his wife placed him on home cpap machine that he usually uses at night  history of present illness: the patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of spinal sarcoidosis with secondary paraplegia who presented with altered mental status , hypoxemic respiratory failure and hypotension  spinal sarcoidosis  8  obstructive sleep apnea  7  diabetes  6  pulmonary embolism  5  aspiration  4  pneumonia  3  hypoxic respiratory failure  2  urosepsis  list of problems: 1"

maintenance iv fluids until cleared to eat by speech and swallow  9  he was discharged on coumadin 5 mg , which is his home dose to follow up at his coumadin clinic 2 on the day of discharge  the day presumed pneumonia seen on chest x-ray for a total of a 10-day course  id: his urine was found to have proteus , resistant to macrobid , and klebsiella , resistant to ampicillin  2  he was also given nebulizer treatments throughout his hospitalization  his oxygen requirement was back to baseline at the time of discharge , and his goal inr was to be on the higher end of the 2 to 3 range , which was goal previously  it was thought that the pe was in the setting of a subtherapeutic inr 2  the following day , his inr was therapeutic at 2 , and on the day of discharge , it was 2 9 and he was continued on his coumadin 7 to 1  at this time , his inr had been subtherapeutic for three days at 1  a pulmonary embolism ct was done that demonstrated a small nonocclusive pulmonary embolism in the posterobasilar segment of the right lower lobe with involving right lower lobe infarct suggestive that he had had a pe that was resolving  he was found to have a chest x-ray within normal limits  on 2/23/2006 , the patient was supposed to go home and found to have a desaturation to high 80's on room air  this is to be used for a uti and pneumonia  his levofloxacin was continued at 500 mg per day for a total 10-day course on 6/10/2006  the vancomycin was discontinued on 4/3/2006 , and the ceftazidime was discontinued on 2/4/206  he was initially treated for pneumonia with ceftazidime , levofloxacin , and vancomycin  bipap was used at night as he had used at home for a sleep apnea with o2 saturations in the high 90's on room air during the day  hypoxemia: he was intubated at the time of admission and extubated a day later on 5/9/2006  hospital course by problem: 1  assessment: this is a 66-year-old man with spinal sarcoidosis and secondary paraplegia , who presented with altered mental status , hypoxemic respiratory failure , and hypotension , who had urosepsis and pneumonia and found later on admission to have pulmonary embolism  abdominal and chest ct showed bibasilar airspace opacities , left greater than right , with aspiration versus pneumonia , bilateral hydronephrosis , severe decubitus ulcers , and large gastrohepatic lymph nodes slightly enlarged and calcified  his chest x-ray showed retrocardiac opacity that was thought to be aspiration versus pneumonia  his ekg was in normal sinus rhythm with an old right bundle-branch block and left axis deviation , first-degree av block  his ua was significant for 3+ protein , trace glucose , negative ketones , 3+ leukocyte esterase , negative nitrites , 4-10 red blood cells , 4+ bacteria , and 3+ triple phosphate crystals  his urine and blood tox screens were negative  he had negative cardiac enzymes 4 , and his platelets were 343 , 000 6 , his white count was 9  his hematocrit was 34  his lfts were within normal limits 9 , otherwise , his chem-7 was within normal limits  laboratory studies: notable for an elevated creatinine of 2  he had an ostomy and suprapubic catheter in place  he was neurologically moving all four extremities and following commands  he had a large sacral decubitus ulcer with bone exposed that was foul smelling on his sacrum  his extremities had chronic venous stasis changes of right and lower extremities with areas of no skin breakdown  his abdomen was obese , large , soft , nondistended and nontender , with positive bowel sounds  his heart was in regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs , rubs or gallops  his lungs were clear anteriorly  heent: sluggish pupils  in general , he was intubated and responsive to simple commands 4 , heart rate 105 , blood pressure 136/67 , his o2 saturation was 100% on ac 700 with peep of 5  physical examination on admission: his temperature was 97  allergies: no known drug allergies  , and calcium 950 mg daily d i  , and she was incontinent of urine and overall more comfortable with catheter in place  if needed for further antibiotics , a picc line was placed on march , 2005 , after her prior picc line clotted  repeat cultures showed bacteria in her urine; however , she was clinically asymptomatic , it was felt that this is more consistent with colonization and no further treatment was instituted  a long-term foley catheter was removed  for her urinary tract infection , she was initially treated with levofloxacin and transitioned to bactrim based on antibiogram sensitivities  she was given a five-day course of levofloxacin ( used to address recurrent uti ) and then a two-day course of ancef , her cellulitis cleared with this regimen  she should continue on her current torsemide and limit her daily salt intake , and restrict herself to 2 liters per day for her right upper extremity cellulitis  her admission weight was 133 kg and her discharge weight 122 kg  twice per day o  for her tricuspid valve  normal right ventricle and structure with mild to moderately reduced systolic function in her right ventricle  echocardiogram of her heart showed an ejection fraction of 55% tissue  2+ edema in her legs to her knees  physical exam was significant for bibasilar crackles in her lungs  she was 95% saturated on 3 liters  her blood pressure was 130/57 , and her pulse 120 in sinus tachycardia  physical examination: she was afebrile  medications on admission: vitamin c , imuran , phoslo , iron sulfate , deltasone , coumadin , aranesp , dilaudid for pain , lactulose , reglan , sarna topical , senokot , ambien for sleep , miconazole powder , cyclosporine , celexa , and lasix 80 mg once per day  allergies: she had allergies to penicillin and codeine , but the reactions are unknown  her inpatient issues included management of her heart failure , right upper extremity cellulitis , urinary tract infection , chronic anemia , diabetes , and evaluation of her hip by orthopedics  she was found to be vancomycin resistant enterococcus positive , but repeated cultures demonstrated mrsa negative  she was anemic  she had a right upper arm cellulitis and urinary tract infection on screening urinalysis  a head ct showed no acute processes  here , her mental status was borderline upon admission , but it improved with discontinuation of standing analgesic and decreasing of her clonazepam  her chest x-ray was consistent with congestive heart failure , and she was transferred to ckmond kinga quinaualv medical center with the request of her daughter for further management of her heart failure  halnon is a 67-year-old female with multiple medical comorbidities and a past medical history significant for cardiac transplant in 1993 , and hip replacement in july 2005 , complicated by wound infection , and need for prolonged rehabilitation who presented from port medical center to ephma mersources ni memorial hospital with three days of progressive asymptomatic , it was felt that this is more consistent with colonization and no further treatment was instituted  a long-term foley catheter was removed  for her urinary tract infection , she was however , the patient is informed , as the rehab hospital and the discharge summary , which show that the patient seem to develop any evidence of infection that he should be reevaluated by a physician  the patient appears well , and states that he is feeling at his best since the accident  the results are pending at the time of dictation , however , will be followed up prior to the patient's discharge from the hospital  in addition , a repeat urinalysis was performed  otherwise , it was essentially negative  this was reviewed with an attending radiologist who reported low lung volumes  the chest x-ray was performed on the 18 of april , which demonstrated no infiltrate  it was felt that this probably represented stress , given all the recent procedures that were done , including the catheterization and the electrophysiology studies , rather than a2 infection  of note , his white count was trending upwards , on the last two days of admission  infectious disease: there was no evidence of any acute infection  4  he was encouraged to take several deep breaths per hour to reduce the risk of atelectasis or pneumonia  this pain was well controlled with the combination of dilaudid and oxycodone  it was therefore felt that given the negative enzymes and the negative cath , and the known rib fractures that the chest pain was strictly a result of a musculoskeletal pain  however , he adamantly denied any pain throughout his chest wall upon inspiring  the rib fractures were felt to be the source of his pain , he continue to complain of some inspiratory pain throughout his chest  in addition , he was noted to have several rib fractures  with the impression of the orthopedic service that no acute intervention was needed , and that he should follow-up with sports medicine or orthopedics in approximately 3-4 weeks  he saw physical therapy , which felt that further therapy would be indicated  he remained in a knee immobilizer  there was no evidence of fracture  this showed tears of the medial and lateral menisci  musculoskeletal: he was seen by the orthopedic service in the emergency department at the time of the trauma , he ultimately had an mri that was performed of his knee  3  given artifact , this could be further followed up with an outpatient venous duplex of the carotid arteries  the right bifurcation is probably without significant stenosis , however , could not be completed excluded  the mri/mra of the neck was essentially normal , however , the left bifurcation was thought to be without any significant stenosis  an mra of his head and neck demonstrated tortuous vertebrobasilar system  given the fact that the patient remained asymptomatic , and had a normal neurological exam , and radiographic data demonstrated that this infarct was more than 10 days old , and this was not further addressed  it was most likely represented an old cva , which was not previously detected  therefore , this was not felt to be either the cause nor an affect of the motor vehicle collision  therefore , given the fact that signal was seen on the t2 and flair , not on the diffusion-weighted , it was felt that this was at least 10 days old  there was a region of increase signal intensity on the t2 and flair images , involving the vasoganglion , extending the corona radiata  the diffusion-weighted images demonstrated no evidence of any abnormality was found to be working adequately  he had a pacemaker inserted  they were unable to induce any ventricular tachycardia or other dysrhythmias during the prolonged ep studies  he also went to the electrophysiology lab  it was felt , however , this was unchanged from prior studies  please see the dictated cardiology reports for the findings of the cath lab  he went to the cardiac cath lab , which demonstrated some coronary artery disease  he had serial enzymes , which were performed , he was ruled out for myocardial infarction  he also had an additional zoll pacer pads , as well as the prophylaxis and subcutaneous heparin for dvt prophylaxis  prophylaxis  ) 9  ( his mild subclinical hyperthyroidism may have contributed to his low mood as apathetic hyperthyroidism in a gentleman of this age is not uncommon  psychiatric service was consulted and felt like he had a resolving medical delirium and there is no indication for further pharmacal or psychodynamic therapy at this time neuropsych  8  urine cultures grew out greater than 100 , 000 colonies of serratia marcescens and he was given a 14-day course of renally dosed levofloxacin with good resolution of his symptoms  upon presentation , the patient after a foley was placed became a little delirious and hypoglycemic  infectious disease  7  he was making good urine and had no evidence of residual urinary tract infection 7 and falling at the time of discharge and his bun was 67  his creatinine was 2 19  we ended up re-dosing his digoxin to three times weekly from every other day because of the dig level of 0  we wanted to avoid as much contrast dye as possible during this hospital stay because of his renal insufficiency  he has had adverse reaction to contrast dye in the past with a creatinine bump to nearly 7  the patient has baseline chronic renal insufficiency presumably due to a combination of diabetes and hypertension  renal  6 5 mcg and we recommend a tsh to be checked in late february 2004 219 as well as a normal t4 , this is suggestive of clinical hypothyroidism , which is consistent with over replacement with synthroid such as maintenance synthroid dose is decreased from 75 mcg to 60  furthermore , the patient was found to have a tsh of 0  respectively as well as a lispro scale at the time of discharge m  and p m  he was euglycemic on 15 and 10 of nph in the a  this resolved after approximately 24 hours of holding his long-acting insulin and giving him glucose replacement therapy  he was briefly hypoglycemic during his initial hospital course because of a urinary tract infection  the patient has very difficult to control diabetes mellitus , and was maintained on both nph and lispro sliding scale while in house  endocrine  5  the patient was sating 98% on room air at the time of discharge  a more likely explanation for these findings is a residual pulmonary edema relating to inadequate diuresis with his congestive heart failure  it is unclear if the patient has underlying restrictive lung disease given the absence of definitive interstitial process on high resolution chest ct 5  his corrected dlco is 13  his lung volumes are approximately 50% predicted suggestive of a restrictive process and his dlco both corrected and uncorrected are 50% predicted  he has both decreased fvc and fev1 , but an fev1 and fvc percent that is most consistent with a mild restriction  this gives an fev1 to fvc percent of 71% 33 liters 88 liters and an fev1 of 1  pulmonary function tests revealed an fvc of 1  he also had pulmonary function tests  he had a high resolution chest ct , which showed mild ground glass infiltrate at the bases consistent with pulmonary edema and no evidence of interstitial process  given the fact that the patient had a normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and elevated pulmonary artery pressures , a brief investigation of pulmonary parenchymal disease was undertaken  pulmonary  4  the patient is not at this time a candidate for resynchronization biventricular pacer therapy because his ejection fraction of 45% , even if his qrs interval is greater than 150 ms  he had a few rounds of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia less than 8 beats every time during his hospital stay  his electrolytes were replete and he is on a low-dose beta-blocker  he was maintained on telemetry throughout his hospital stay  the patient has a dual-chambered pacemaker  rhythm  3  the patient's heart failure regimen includes standing lasix , carvedilol , isordil and hydralazine , as well as digoxin for symptomatic improvement  on an outpatient basis in the future , we would suggest the patient have a trial of ace or arb to optimize his after-load reduction and neurohormonal activation with his heart failure 5 on ace inhibition  in the past , he had had a rise in his potassium to 5  of note , the patient has been exposed to ace inhibition in the past and is currently not on an ace inhibitor  by discharge , the patient was actually becoming hypertensive again and he was started on amlodipine , a calcium channel blocker , which he has tolerated in the past  his symptoms improved and we were able to diurese another 2 liters of the patient 7  his creatinine decreased with after-load reduction to 2  at this point , his after-load reduction was maximized with combination of hydralazine and isordil with good effect  there was some initial false elevation because of inadequate sedation while in the cath lab , and the patient was transferred for 48 hours of tailored therapy to the cardiac care unit where he had a pulmonary artery catheter in place  his ra pressure was 8  his pulmonary capillary wedge pressure was determined to be 16 and his pulmonary artery pressure 56/18  the patient was taken to the cardiovascular diagnostic laboratory and received a right heart catheterization  given the fact of his tenuous renal status , we wanted to avoid further diuresis or after-load reduction until we knew exactly what his right and left heart filling pressures were  at this point , his pulmonary edema had resolved and his oxygen requirement was decreased  he was initially diuresed approximately 3 liters with a combination of lasix and natrecor  the patient had an ejection fraction of 45% upon admission with moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation  pump  2  coronary artery disease was felt to be a noncontributory factor to his chf exacerbation  by discharge , he was ambulating halls and was chest tightness free  he was maintained on optimum medical management with the caveat that cardiac catheterization in this gentleman who had already had previous history of renal dysfunction with a creatinine rise to nearly 7 with a dye load was not warranted nor indicated at this time  at this point , he received an adenosine mibi nuclear study , which revealed a known distal anterior wall scar with a very small surrounding region of reversible ischemia that was felt to be nonrevascularizable  eventually , the patient received 48 hours of intravenous heparin as well as iv nitroglycerin and was chest pain free  his enzymes trended down and were negative after the initial check 13 , which was felt as demand ischemia related to systemic hypertension and pulmonary hypertension  he initially came in with a troponin of 0  he is maintained on aspirin , plavix , low dose beta-blocker with carvedilol as well as ace inhibitor and statin  the patient has an extensive history of coronary artery disease  ischemia  brief resume of hospital course: 1 4 , and pt-t was 56 on heparin drip 3 , his hematocrit was 29 1 , a bun of 76 , potassium of 5  admission laboratories: significant for a creatinine of 3  ekg at baneers hospital revealed a dual chamber pacemaker with left bundle-branch pattern and no significant st wave changes and an occasional pvc  he had no pedal edema and 1+ dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally  his extremities were warm  he had no fluid waves and positive bowel sounds  his abdomen was mildly distended  he had no s3 , and no s4  his heart was regular rate and rhythm with a 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex with radiation to the left axilla  he had no dullness  his lungs had rales bilaterally , approximately half way up  his jugular venous pressure was 7 cm  upon presentation , the patient was afebrile , had a heart rate of 82 , blood pressure of 138/64 and was sating 96% on 5 liters of nasal canula  this is consistent with an echocardiogram that he received in 7/25   he was transferred to me ale firstray hospital , started on a nitroglycerin drip as well as a heparin drip for presumed coronary artery disease , a repeat echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 50% , anterior wall distal dyskinesis from an old myocardial infarction and moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation  he was given some lasix and had echocardiogram , had initially revealed an ejection fraction of 35% 13  at the outside hospital when he presented , his ekg showed a baseline left bundle-branch block and had a troponin of 0  he has had no syncope , palpitations , but has had some mild nausea without emesis  the patient had these worsening heart failure symptoms after a trip to i hwy , ny vale , michigan 34152 , some dietary indiscretion and a five-pound weight gain  he was transferred to baspit hospital where he received most of his cardiac care  he presents after coming to an outside hospital with three to four days of these worsening symptoms  he is presented with three weeks of increasing orthopnea , dyspnea , and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea with rare chest tightness without radiation and onset of symptoms mainly while recumbent 8 , diabetes mellitus ( insulin dependent ) , hyperlipidemia , and a pace maker for symptomatic bradycardia  he has a history of coronary artery disease with an mi in 1994 and four-vessel cabg with subsequently placed five stents in 2002 for graft and native vessel stenosis , hypertension , chronic renal insufficiency with a baseline creatinine of 2  brief history of present illness: the patient is a pleasant 78-year-old gentleman who presents with shortness of breath and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea for approximately three weeks  allergies: penicillins  mitral regurgitation  10  mild pulmonary hypertension  9  coronary artery disease  8  dyslipidemia  7  chronic renal " she was thus started on iv heparin with achievement of therapeutic ptt prior to switching to oral coumadin without complications  given the patient's history of dilated cardiomyopathy , off anticoagulation , an extensive discussion of the chest ct findings with the chest radiologist and pulmonary consult team , it was felt that the patient should be treated empirically for a pulmonary embolus  no endobronchial lesions or lymphadenopathy were noted  she thus underwent a chest ct on 5/16/94 with demonstration of a large peripheral , red , right lower lobe opacity , highly suggestive of a right lower lobe pulmonary infarction  as her symptoms and chest x-ray cleared , it was felt that a chest ct would be valuable in evaluating her left lower lobe for possible endobronchial lesion leading to volume loss  the patient was thus treated with aggressive iv diuresis with excellent symptomatic result  she was seen in consultation by the pulmonary service which felt that a therapeutic trial of aggressive diuresis was warranted prior to any more aggressive intervention such as bronchoscopy or repeat thoracentesis  the patient was started on empiric course of antibiotics including cefotaxime and clarithromycin  this clinical picture was felt to be mostly from a progressive infectious process superimposed on underlying congestive heart failure versus post-obstructive infection negative  the patient underwent ultrasound guided thoracentesis complicated by a pneumothorax requiring chest tube placement  she was then admitted on 0/29 after she was found to have a large left-sided pleural effusion  she was treated with increased lasix and digoxin and an empiric course of amoxicillin with little change in her symptoms  subsequently she had done quite well until february of 1994 when she presented with mild cough productive of white phlegm and increasing symptoms of right and left-sided heart failure  the patient eventually underwent epep studies with therapeutic ablation  she had subsequent development of svt with a rapid ventricular rate of approximately 180  she was then treated with digoxin , lasix , captopril and coumadin with good result  she was diagnosed with cardiomyopathy felt secondary to adriamycin toxicity  the patient then presented in august of 1992 with progressive dyspnea on exertion , found to have an ejection fraction of 17% " given the patient's history of dilated cardiomyopathy , off anticoagulation , an extensive discussion of the chest ct findings with the chest radiologist and pulmonary consult team , it was felt that the patient should be treated empirically for a pulmonary embolus  no endobronchial lesions or lymphadenopathy were noted  she thus underwent a chest ct on 5/16/94 with demonstration of a large peripheral , red , right lower lobe opacity , highly suggestive of a right lower lobe pulmonary infarction  as her symptoms and chest x-ray cleared , it was felt that a chest ct would be valuable in evaluating her left lower lobe for possible endobronchial lesion leading to volume loss  the patient was thus treated with aggressive iv diuresis with excellent symptomatic result  she was seen in consultation by the pulmonary service which felt that a therapeutic trial of aggressive diuresis was warranted prior to any more aggressive intervention such as bronchoscopy or repeat thoracentesis  the patient was started on empiric course of antibiotics including cefotaxime and clarithromycin  this clinical picture was felt to be mostly from a progressive infectious process superimposed on underlying congestive heart failure versus post-obstructive infection versus atelectasis with an endobronchial lesion  hospital course: the patient was admitted with a picture of chronic productive cough , progressive dyspnea with low grade fevers and increased white blood cell count , in addition to new opacity on chest x-ray  ekg showed sinus rhythm at 98 , left axis deviation , normal " id: on admission to micu , given her positive urinalysis , she was placed on cefotaxime for gram negative coverage  3  she was maintained on cpap during her hospitalization stay; however , the patient informed the treating team that she would not be using a cpap machine once she returned home secondary to the inconvenience and discomfort  it was felt that the patient likely had obstructive sleep apnea secondary to her body habitus  these studies taken together alleviated the concern of pe or dvt in her  in addition , she also had negative lenis  a vq scan was obtained , which was read as low probability for pe  a spiral ct was obtained that was nondiagnostic secondary to her body habitus  with her body habitus putting her at risk for dvt and pe , an echocardiogram which showed evidence of pulmonary hypertension raised the concern for pe being responsible for her symptoms of tachypnea and tachycardia  an echocardiogram was obtained to assess her left ventricular function in the context of her non-q-wave mi , which was notable for normal left ventricular function , with an ef of 50% , hypokinesis of the inferior septum , a right ventricle that was mildly enlarged , with mildly decreased systolic function , normal aortic valve , mild tr , and mild mr , and a pulmonary artery pressure of 39 mm of mercury plus right atrial pressure consistent with pulmonary hypertension and no pericardial effusion  as her creatinine had improved concurrent with hydration , she was gently diuresed  pulmonary: posthydration , the patient was noted to have increasing respiratory rates and o2 requirements and rales on exam  2  this issue will need to be addressed as an outpatient  on the day of discharge , she continued to have elevated blood sugars &gt;200 and required coverage with insulin sliding scale d i  despite escalating her dose of nph up to 65 u subcu b  she was eventually transitioned to nph with insulin sliding scale coverage  she was placed on an insulin drip and hydrated with intravenous fluids , with improvement  endocrine: as noted above , the patient presented with bka in the setting of urosepsis and a non-q-wave mi  hospital course: her hospital course by habitus  these studies taken together alleviated the concern of pe or dvt in her  in addition , she also had negative lenis  a vq scan was obtained , which was read as low probability for pe  a spiral very difficult to control   2  difficult to control on multiple regimen and follow at lch   hypertension  past medical history: 1  review of systems: negative for chest pain , shortness of breath , dyspnea on exertion , abdominal pain , nausea , vomiting , fevers , chills , and dysuria  the patient was transferred to the cardiology team on march , 2005 , for further medical management prior to cardiac catheterization for the non-st-elevation mi  secondary to the patient's mental status and question of inability to swallow , an ng tube was placed; however , it was self-discontinued by the patient on july , 2005  an echocardiogram was obtained and was negative for any cardiac sources and emboli and with a negative bubble study  an mri/mra was obtained which showed small vessel disease consistent with hypertension-induced cerebrovascular accident and no evidence of embolism  the ccu course was also complicated by the patient developing left-sided weakness in the left lower extremity on icu day #5 , which was concerning for cva  he was started on vancomycin , ceftazidime , and levofloxacin was added 1 on ccu day #3 , and he was started on broad spectrum antibiotics for presumptive icu pneumonia  ccu course was complicated by the patient spiking a fever to 104  iv labetalol was discontinued after that episode 5 seconds on july , 2005 , with no symptoms  the patient also had an episode of sinus pause of greater than 2  blood pressure medications were restarted with systolic blood pressure goal of 140 o  his nipride was weaned on day #5 and his p  this increase was in the setting of confusion ??___??  however , his blood pressure continued to rise ??___?? on ccu day #4 and nipride drip was initiated d i  , and hydralazine 50 q d i  , lopressor 100 q d i  , captopril 25 t d  the patient came in from the pamc with a nitroglycerin drip , which was weaned and transitioned to norvasc 5 mg q  his blood pressure continued to be very difficult to control  the patient was continued to be maintained on aspirin , plavix , and lipitor while integrilin was discontinued on ccu day #2 as the patient was not stable for cardiac catheterization  his ekg showed signs of evolving anterior mi 8 , which trended down 2 , and troponin of 13  at the ston n ccu , he was found to have a cardiac enzyme leak with a peak ck of 286 , ck-mb of 6  at the mancharl tuvange memorial hospital icu , the patient also had marked hyperglycemia and was put on a ??___?? protocol  he was started on asa , heparin , beta-blocker , statin , and integrilin and transferred to the ih on january , 2005 , for management for possible catheterization  during the admission to nymo hospital , he had lateral st segment depressions on multiple ekgs and a non-st-elevation mi ( nstemi ) with a peak troponin of 20 on june , 2005 , a peak ck of 430 , and a peak mb of 20  haldol and zyprexa n r  the patient was also frequently agitated requiring increasing doses of versed and fentanyl as well as p  there was a concern for aortic dissection on echocardiogram , but an mri/mra revealed no dissection  the patient received a tee on june , 2005 , which showed concentric lvh , no wall motion abnormalities , and ef of 45%  the patient's hypertension was difficult to control , requiring labetalol initially and then a successful regimen of iv nitroglycerin , nitroprusside , hydralazine , and lopressor  hospital icu where he was diuresed aggressively f  the patient was then intubated for airway protection and oxygenation and admitted to the r  he was found to be hypertensive to the 200/100 , with florid pulmonary edema and hypertensive encephalopathy  he has increased dyspnea on exertion , needing to use a cpap at night  his wife reported that he has been experiencing gradually worsening shortness of breath since the afternoon of march , 2005 , without any chest pain  genuario is a 44-year-old married hispanic male with a history of diabetes; hypertension; hypercholesterolemia; and obstructive sleep apnea , on cpap , who presented to the ryans valley hospital emergency room on june , 2005 , with complaint of shortness of breath  history of present illness: the patient , mr  pneumonia  6  status post cerebrovascular accident  5  obstructive sleep apnea , on cpap  4  hyperlipidemia  3  diabetes  2  hypertension since at least 1995  list of problems and diagnoses: 1  principal diagnoses: pulmonary edema , hypertensive urgency , non-st-elevation myocardial infarction , status post catheterization"

dramatically  for a time , the patient was placed in a right lower extremity extension brace which provided some measure of relief; however , upon regular examination of her right lower extremity , it was noted that she was gradually developing pressure ulcers secondary to the extension brace  a fair amount of her pain was determined to be secondary to her right foot ulcer; however , the patient was also noted to have significant pain associated with her contracted right lower extremity  neurological: the patient demonstrated significant issues with pain control for the duration of her stay remained for the duration of her stay  for a detailed description of this operative procedure , please see the relevant operative note  the patient remained in stable condition through postoperative day #7 at which point , she was returned to the operating room for a great toe amputation and definitive closure of her right foot wound  at this point , the patient's vac dressing was changed to demonstrate a well-vascularized actively bleeding wound with granulation tissue and no signs of wound necrosis  at this point , the patient was switched to vancomycin therapy only and was continued on vac therapy through postoperative day #3  her operative cultures subsequently grew out coagulase-negative staph which was sensitive to both keflex and vancomycin  following her procedure , the patient was empirically continued on vancomycin and ceftazidime  the ulcers on the lateral right foot were not debrided at this time  the patient's great toe was left in place with moderate debridement of the deep tissues  patient tolerated the procedure well and during the procedure , the patient's ulcer base was found to be contiguous with the first metatarsal head periosteum , and therefore , a metatarsal head excision was performed  for a detailed description of the patient's operative procedure , please the relevant operative note  on hospital day #3 , the patient was brought to the operating room for debridement of her right foot  following her angiogram and percutaneous intervention , the patient was noted to demonstrate excellent right lower extremity dp and pt pulses which no evidence of acute hemodynamic instability or compromise  2  the patient otherwise remained intact from a neurological perspective for the duration of her stay , demonstrating frequent emotional ability consistent with her baseline examination  a neurology and pain service consultation was obtained and the patient was subsequently recommended for zanaflex therapy which subsequently improved her pain control dramatically  for a time , the patient was placed in a right lower extremity extension brace which provided some measure of relief; however , upon regular examination of her right lower extremity , it was noted that she was gradually developing pressure ulcers secondary to the extension brace  a fair amount of her pain was determined to be secondary to her right foot ulcer; however , the patient was also noted to have significant pain associated with her contracted right lower extremity  neurological: the patient demonstrated significant issues with pain control for the duration of her stay  a general overview of the patient's hospital course by system is as follows: 1  the patient tolerated the procedure well and was subsequently returned to the regular outpatient floor where she remained for the duration of her stay  for a detailed description of this operative procedure , please see the relevant operative note  the patient remained in stable condition through postoperative day #7 at which point , she was returned to the operating room for a great toe amputation and definitive closure of her right foot wound  at this point , the patient's vac dressing was changed to demonstrate a well-vascularized actively bleeding wound with granulation tissue and no signs of wound necrosis  at this point , the patient was switched to vancomycin therapy only and was continued on vac therapy through postoperative day #3  her operative cultures subsequently grew out coagulase-negative staph which was sensitive to both keflex and vancomycin  following her procedure , the patient was empirically continued on vancomycin and ceftazidime  the ulcers on the lateral right foot were not debrided at this time  the patient's great toe was left in place with moderate debridement of the deep tissues  patient tolerated the procedure well and during the procedure , the patient's ulcer base was found to be contiguous with the first metatarsal head periosteum , and therefore , a metatarsal head excision was performed  for a detailed description of the patient's operative procedure , please the relevant operative note  on hospital day #3 , the patient was brought to the operating room for debridement of her right foot  following her angiogram and percutaneous intervention , the patient was noted to demonstrate excellent right lower extremity dp and pt pulses which remained palpable through the duration of her hospital course  the patient sustained a mild groin hematoma on the left at the access site but had no change in her pulse exam there afterwards  a distal stenosis of the external iliac was opened with balloon angioplasty to good effect   an angiogram performed on hospital day #2 , revealed a right external iliac occlusion which was stented near the bifurcation of the internal and external iliac vessels  the patient was also continued on her prior dose of macrobid for previously-diagnosed uti with her antibiotic regimen to be discontinued for fibrocystic breast disease  status post ivc umbrella placement in 1981  history of deep venous thromboses in 1981  sjorgren's syndrome  type ii hyperlipidemia  hypertension  past medical history: coronary artery disease , status post myocardial infarction as above  the patient then presented to the adin hospital and was then transferred to dutchessa hospital   the chest pressure and shortness of breath decreased with rest  on 8/11 , the patient while walking at the jose xingsterka sno became acutely short of breath with 2/10 substernal chest pressure radiating to the right arm without nausea , vomiting or diaphoresis or lightheadedness  the patient stayed at home for the next three weeks , symptom-free  the patient was sent home on ventolin inhaler  o2 saturation was 95%  the patient was transferred to west hospital where she underwent a v-q scan , the results of which showed low probability of pulmonary embolus  there were no ekg changes  during the second bronkosol treatment , the patient developed 2/10 substernal chest pressure radiating to the left arm which was relieved completely with one sublingual nitroglycerin  the patient was treated for presumed asthma with bronkosol nebulizers and solu-medrol  her respiratory rate was 30 , and o2 saturation was 85%  she presented to li general hospital with worsening dyspnea , wheezing  on 0/28/91 , the patient was having progressive shortness of breath and dyspnea on exertion that morning  also in march of 1991 , the patient had pulmonary function tests which showed normal spirometry and lung volumes  in march of 1991 , the patient had an ett in which she exercised for four minutes , 28 seconds achieving a peak heart rate of 103 and a peak blood pressure of 150/60 , stopping secondary to fatigue and shortness of breath without chest pain or ekg changes  in may of 1988 , the patient had an echocardiogram which showed significant lvh , decreased lv compliance , borderline left atrial enlargement and no regional wall motion abnormalities  she had only minimal anginal symptoms and shortness of breath during that period  the patient was managed medically and did well for the next seven years from a cardiac standpoint  the angioplasty procedure was not done  the patient was then transferred to rocke elel word hospital for ptca  the patient was transferred to tampnew hospital where a cardiac catheterization was performed which showed an 80% proximal lad lesion and a 30% mid rca lesion  ekg showed global t wave inversions  in 1983 , the patient was admitted to nocksu hospital where she ruled in for a non q wave myocardial infarction with peak ck of 182 , 7% mb  history of present illness: the patient's coronary risk factors include hypertension , elevated cholesterol , 25-pack-year smoking history and a positive family history  identification data: this patient is a 59-year-old white female with known coronary artery disease , past history of myocardial infarction admitted 1/24/91 with three weeks of worsening dyspnea on exertion and chest discomfort  discharge diagnosis: coronary artery disease"

" for volume overload n r 125 once a day , torsemide 200 mg twice , and metolazone p 5 mg once a day , isordil 20 mg three times a day , digoxin 0  medications on admission: aldactone 25 mg once a day , k-dur 40 meq once a day , lisinopril 2 5 at times 2 to 3  past medical history: in addition to the cardiomyopathy is chronic renal insufficiency with the creatinine ranging from 1  of note , he has been previously on a transplant list , but has been delisted given his noncompliance and continuation of tobacco use  because of these symptoms consistent with decompensated heart failure , his physicians suggested that he be admitted to the hospital for management of his decompensated heart failure  consequently , he has noticed a worsening in his exercise tolerance , worsening orthopnea , and most notably an increase in abdominal girth  currently , he states that he has been eating \"salty foods , \" and has been drinking a lot of extra fluids because he has been feeling dry and is not always taking his medications  he also has a history of dietary fluid intake and medications noncompliance leading to heart failure exacerbations  he denies , chest pain , palpitations , or peripheral edema  he also admits that he has been having increasing orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  at baseline , he has a one staircase exercise tolerance before becoming short of breath  he was also status post icd placement in 2001  history of present illness: this is a 36-year-old man with a history of a familial cardiomyopathy , ejection fraction estimated at around 15% with marked left and right chamber enlargement , severe mitral regurgitation , tricuspid regurgitation , and pa pressures of 51 plus right atrium , as per an echo in 2003 d"

chest x-ray showed right effusion and her cardiac enzymes were elevated with a troponin of 0  her systolic blood pressure came up to 100 without intervention , but she was sent to ster valley general hospital er for further evaluation   history of present illness: the patient is a 75-year-old  african-american woman with chronic renal insufficiency , coronary artery disease , and diabetes and " on postoperative day #3 , the patient had atrial fibrillation which was treated and controlled pharmacologically , and also the patient was treated with prophylactic anticoagulation with coumadin  the patient's intra-aortic balloon pump was subsequently removed without further incident , and the patient was subsequently transferred to the floor in stable condition  on postoperative day #1 , the patient self-extubated himself and resultantly had an adequate arterial blood gas , thus not requiring emergent intubation  the patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the cardiac surgery unit in stable condition  hospital course: the patient went to the operating room on 11/23 , had a coronary artery bypass graft x three with a saphenous vein graft to the lad , first branch of the obtuse marginal and the posterior descending artery  there were no varices noted  the patient had 2+ dorsalis and posterior tibial pulses bilaterally and on the right femoral artery had a right intra-aortic balloon pump in place  extremities: no clubbing , cyanosis or edema  abdomen was soft , nontender , nondistended with positive bowel sounds  no murmurs appreciated  normal s1 , s2  regular rate and rhythm  heart: a balloon pump was in place  carotids were 2+ without bruits  no lymphadenopathy  no thyromegaly  there was no hepatojugular reflux  neck: jugular venous pressure was about 8 cm  oropharynx clear  intraocular muscles intact  heent: pupils are equal and reactive to light and accommodation 1 , heart rate 66 , sinus 137/57 , saturating at 97% and 100% face mask who is in no acute distress lying in bed with an intra-aortic balloon pump  physical examination: on physical examination , the patient's temperature is 98  allergies: the patient has no known drug allergies day  , glyburide , lisinopril 20 po q d i  medications on admission: the patient was admitted on the following medications: diltiazem 60 t  past medical history: the patient's past medical history is inclusive of status post percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty in '85 at ason medical center , coronary artery disease , diabetes , hypertension and ruptured appendectomy 25 years prior to admission  the patient was placed on an intra-aortic balloon pump in preparation for coronary artery bypass surgery  at the hitchter university medical center , the patient was cathed and had 100% stenotic mid left anterior descending , 90% ulcerated obtuse marginal first branch , 60 to 70% stenotic right coronary artery and anterior apical aneurysm was noted  , the patient had recurrent chest pain with elevations in v1 through 6 , lead , 1 , avl and the patient was subsequently transferred to the pepor el medical center of  m  at 1:00 a  the patient received front-loaded tpa , heparin , aspirin , morphine sulfate and nifedipine  blood pressure was 152/95  the patient was ruled in for anterior wall myocardial infarction with st elevations 4 to 5 mm in v1  the patient subsequently was admitted to agrit medical center and had at least 3 hours of pain at pari   the patient took four to five nitroglycerins without relief  the patient denied nausea or vomiting but says he was diaphoretic  the patient is unable to describe any further symptoms  several days to admission , the patient reports pain and ache over the lower back and flanks as well as substernal chest pain with radiation to the upper left arm  the patient , however , has been able to work and climb stairs and walk about a mile without difficulty  the patient , in 1985 , had a percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty at the ribush bassta syark hospital and has had rule outs since for myocardial infarction with the last one approximately in 1990 at dormro general hospital   the patient has long-standing hypotension of 30 to 40 years  past medical history: the patient's past medical history is significant for diabetes of 20 years without neurological or retinopathy treated with oral hypoglycemics  the patient is a very noncooperative historian  the patient denies cigarettes  the patient's cardiac risk factors include diabetes , hypertension , and positive family history  history of present illness: the patient is a 62-year-old white male status post anterior wall myocardial infarction , status post tpa who presented with post-infarct angina and three-vessel disease by catheterization"

" the patient was continued on her ppi for gerd prophylaxis  she did have some episode of diarrhea prior to admission along with some abdominal cramping  the nausea and vomiting eventually resolved and perhaps this is some type of viral illness or gastroenteritis  it is likely that some of her pain was secondary to hepatic congestion  the overall impression was no evidence of any high-grade bowel obstruction  there is no bowel dilatation seen  there was gas seen within the loops of small bowel as well as the colon  a single frontal view of the abdomen was obtained and is reported in the final radiology report  she had a kub performed for a question of potential bowel obstruction  gi: the patient was initially admitted with some abdominal pain and also nausea and vomiting  3  she did not required any nebulizers during her stay  she continued to sat well on room air  pulmonary: the patient remained stable from her pulmonary standpoint  2  visualized portion of the thoracic aorta revealed minimal atheromatous plaque  there was mild regurgitation present  the tricuspid valve was normal in appearance  there was slight asynchronous motion of the prosthetic valve apparatus that was noted  there was trace mild regurgitation noted  jude's valve was well seated in the mitral position as well  a st  there was no significant aortic regurg that was noted  jude's valve was well a tee performed  d  she will have her medications modified status post her valvular repair in the very near future d i  the patient was discharged on diltiazem 30 mg q  they recommended epicardial lead placement at surgery due to her tachybrady syndrome  she was evaluated by the ep service  on admission , her digoxin was stopped  rhythm: the patient has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation that has been rate controlled with a beta-blocker  c  that is the dosing of lasix on which she is discharged d o  lasix q o  she was then placed back on a regimen of 120 mg of p  after that point , diuresis was slowly modified 9 8 , 1  she was diuresed until there was a subsequent bump in her creatinine to 1  basis d i  her diuresis was continued with 80 mg iv lasix on a b  the patient was admitted and diuresed with iv lasix , so she came down to a euvolemic state  pump: please see cath report as above  b  she had no evidence of major atherosclerotic disease of the coronary arteries  the overall conclusion was elevated right-sided heart pressures  the av was also grossly  the mitral valve was grossly normal with appropriate leaflet motion  the hemodynamics were notable for the following: ra of 12 , pa of 92/23/44 , pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 22 with v waves to 42  her workup was extensive and included a cardiac catheterization , which showed no significant coronary artery disease  bio   the patient laid her head workup for future avr and mvr with the surgical service , with dr  she did fine from the standpoint , had no st changes on any of her ekgs  in addition , she had some slight anemia , which could also be contributed to the demand as well in addition to the clear volume overload  she did have a slight increase of her troponins , which were attributed to mild demand ischemia  ischemia: when the patient was admitted , she was ruled out for an mi  cardiovascular: a  brief hospital course by systems: 1  jude's mvr and avr , congestive heart failure who presents with mild volume overload and abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting  impression: this is a 59-year-old female with a rheumatic heart disease , status post st  there was no evidence of any effusion  chest x-ray: showed mild vascular congestion  there were some nonspecific t-wave inversions  there was a normal access  she had frequent pvcs  it was in junctional rhythm at 65 beats per minute  studies: her ekg showed no change 4 2 , and total protein 7 1 , albumin 4  her liver function tests are notable for alt 56 , ast 83 , alkaline phosphatase is 52 , total bilirubin 0 9 , platelet count 274 , 000 9 , hematocrit 27  cbc is notable for a white blood cell count of 9 3 , glucose 160 2 and 1 4 with a baseline of 1 4 , chloride 93 , bicarbonate 24 , bun 28 , creatinine 1  laboratory exam on admission: sodium 126 , potassium 4  it is slightly pitting  she does have some 1+ lower extremity edema on the right greater than the left  extremities: warm , 1+ dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally  the spleen tip is nonpalpable  her liver edge is not palpable  she has active bowel sounds  her right lower quadrant is slightly tender  abdomen: slightly tympanic  no wheezes or rhonchi are heard  chest: faint crackles at the left base , otherwise clear  her pmi is diffuse , but nondisplaced  she additionally has a right rv heave  there are no rubs or gallops appreciated  she has a 3/6 holosystolic murmur heard at the apex  she has a s1 and s2 that are mechanical in nature  cardiovascular: heart is of regular rate and rhythm with occasional premature beats  there are no carotid bruits and there is no lymphadenopathy present  there was full range of motion  her neck is supple  neck: jvp noted to be approximately 6 cm  there is no erythema or exudate seen within the tonsils  she has a small erosion on the right upper gum  she has moist mucous membrane  her right eye is approximately 3 mm  heent: her left eye is artificial  she is anxious , but pleasant in nature  general: she is alert and oriented x3  these were vitals when the patient arrived to the floor 7 , pulse 60 , blood pressure 111/61 , respiratory rate 30 , o2 saturation 96% on room air  physical examination on admission: vital signs are remarkable for temperature of 98  family history: noncontributory  she has had increased stress at home secondary to a son who has schizophrenia and another son who abuses drugs and has violent tendencies  she used to work as a hairdresser  she does not take any illicit drugs  as far as her alcohol history , she drinks occasional alcohol  her maximum was three to four packs per day for 35 years  social history: the patient quit smoking in 2001  actonel every wednesday  12  iron tablets  11  multivitamin  10 d mitral valve , and avr  in 1991 , she had st  in 1981 , she had porcine mitral valve repair  rheumatic heart disease , status post mitral valve repair and aortic valve repair  past medical history: 1  she reported no change in her bowel , bladder , or urinary habits  she reported no bright red blood per rectum  she reported no fevers , chills , or night sweats  she was able to pass gas  on the floor during the interview , she did have some projectile vomiting  she also complained of 10/10 abdominal pain and was given some dilaudid  she did have some decrease in her shortness of breath shortly thereafter  in the ed , she was given 60 mg of iv lasix with good output per report  she went to her pcp on the day of admission for increasing shortness of breath and was sent to the ed for diuresis  the patient's diarrhea stopped , but she had still remained some abdominal pain and increased cough , which was nonproductive  difficile infection  she had gone to see the ed on the sunday prior to admission where the patient reportedly had a benign exam , low-grade temperature , given recent levaquin for an upper respiratory tract infection , she was then started on flagyl for a possible c  she also notes nausea , vomiting , and some abdominal pain stating that it started about a week and a half ago  the patient says that she does not check her weigh at home , but \"knows\" she is in failure when she is short of breath \" she does not have any lightheadedness , diaphoresis , or radiation of pain  the patient notes that the shortness of breath is \"not angina; i do not have that  she has no increase in her abdominal girth , the patient has two-to three-pillow orthopnea ( from one-pillow orthopnea , one month ago ) , she does have some paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea , she has no increased nocturia  she states that this is her baseline with the right side being more than the left  the patient notes increasing lower extremity edema on the right side greater than the left  she has had increasing shortness of breath as well as dyspnea on exertion since july 2004 and has gotten worse in the past one month , and even significantly worse in the past week  she has been under significant stress at home since last summer and notes slowly declining health since that time  history of present illness: this is 59-year-old female who is status post mitral valve repair , aortic valve repair , history of endocarditis , history of rheumatic heart disease , hypertension , diabetes mellitus , and congestive heart failure who presents with increasing shortness of breath , nausea , vomiting , and abdominal pain  chief complaint: shortness of breath  discharge diagnoses: congestive heart failure , aortic valve and mitral valve dysfunction  service: general medical service , na admit diagnosis: congestive heart failure d"
" she had gone to see the ed on the sunday prior to admission where the patient reportedly had a benign exam , low-grade temperature , given recent levaquin for an upper respiratory tract infection , she was then started on flagyl for a possible c  she also notes nausea , vomiting , and some abdominal pain stating that it started about a week and a half ago  the patient says that she does not check her weigh at home , but \"knows\" she is in failure when she is short of breath \" she does not have any lightheadedness , diaphoresis , or radiation of pain  the patient notes that the shortness of breath is \"not angina; i do not have that  she has no increase in her abdominal girth , the patient has two-to three-pillow orthopnea ( from one-pillow orthopnea , one month ago ) , she does have some paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea , she has no increased nocturia  she states that this is her baseline with the right side being more than the left  the patient notes increasing lower extremity edema on the right side greater than the left  she has had increasing shortness of breath as well as dyspnea on exertion since july 2004 and has gotten worse in the past one month , and even significantly worse in the past week  she has been under significant stress at home since last summer and notes slowly declining health since that time  history of present illness: this is 59-year-old female who is status post mitral valve repair , aortic valve repair , history of endocarditis , history of rheumatic heart disease , hypertension , diabetes mellitus , and congestive heart failure who presents with increasing shortness of breath , nausea , vomiting , and abdominal pain  chief complaint: shortness of breath  discharge diagnoses: congestive heart failure , aortic valve and mitral valve dysfunction  service: general medical service , na admit diagnosis: congestive heart failure d"

" levaquin was given for treatment of her uti  she had a urine sent that showed , the suggestion of a urinary tract infection  the surgery was delayed as a result of this , so an infectious workup could ensue  villata to repair her aortic valve and also her mitral valve  this was one day prior to a planned surgery on may , 2005 with dr  on july , 2005 , the patient was noted to have an increase in her white blood cell count upwards towards the 20 , 000  infectious disease: the patient was stable from an id standpoint during her entire admission  7  they will become again involved with her care as she plans for surgery in the very near future  all of her prescriptions were provided by carl mcclenahan , who is following with the diabetes service  she will continue to take this regimen in home  she was not receiving any of the novolog while at lunch  she also received novolog of 15 units in the morning with breakfast and also 15 at dinner  she also was placed on a sliding scale  she was maintained on a stable regimen of nph 60 units in the morning , nph 30 units in the evening  several modifications were made to her regimen while here to get good control of her blood glucose  endocrine: we appreciated the diabetes service for following her very closely while in-house  6  she has no active issues now 3 2 , 1  when diuresis was held for several days given her markedly increased urine output and as she became more hydrated and euvolemic , her creatinine returned to its baseline of 1 4 on her admission secondary to her ongoing diuresis 3 , 3  it did elevate to as high as 3  renal: her bun and creatinine was relatively stable on admission  5  she has home vna in place  she will continue to take this lovenox as an outpatient and stop it one to two days prior to her surgery as instructed  with a renal dosing d i  on discharge , the patient was transitioned to lovenox 60 mg b  with regard to anticoagulation , she was placed on the heparin drip at 950 units per hour to maintain a ptt between 60 and 80 secondary to her mechanical valves that are in place  she required no subsequent transfusions thereafter  her hematocrit bumped appropriately to 30 or 31  she did have a slight dip in her hematocrit at one point requiring two units of packed red blood cells  we were not concerned with keeping her hematocrit 30 or above at all times given her clean coronary arteries seen from the left and also right heart catheterization  heme: her hematocrit remained relatively stable during her stay with averaging of 26 to 27 as far as her hematocrit  4  she should continue using  in addition , she was given prescription for colace and also senokot today  , which she will continue to take as an outpatient d i  b o  she was discharged on omeprazole 20 mg p  while " history of the present illness: this is a 50 year-old woman with a history of end stage renal disease , status post transplant ( cadaveric ) in february of 1997 , history of insulin dependent diabetes mellitus , and coronary artery disease , status post coronary artery bypass grafting in february of 1996 , left internal mammary artery to the left anterior descending and saphenous vein graft to obtuse marginal , who reports having done fairly well until six months ago when she had an episode of chest pain which was relieved by nitroglycerin  leezer is a 50 year-old woman with a history of end stage renal disease , status post renal transplant and a history of coronary artery disease , status post coronary artery bypass grafting , now with syncope and palpitations"
